Not only did Bill W. experience abandonment from his parents as a child, his high school sweetheart , who he intended to marry, died suddenly. He also was a WW1 veteran. There is little doubt he experienced  some trauma during his war time experience. His first â€œspiritual experienceâ€ was of the psychedelic nature as a result of the Bella Donna treatment he was prescribed by his doctor during detox. After helping to establish AA, in 1944 he went through a deep depression that lasted eleven years. In 1956 Bill was prescribed LSD to help him with his depression. It was being used at the time to also treat alcoholism and schizophrenia. He said the LSD restored a lot that his depression had destroyed. He began to see and feel color in life again. The guru bit really is of interest to me because I have had a rough experience in my journey to peace. I had a rough experience with drug dependency throughout my teen and adult years. The rehab centers and AA were the main course when I started my journey to get my life in order. Although I managed to cycle out of the major destructive lifestyle The twelve step indoctrination eventually hindered me and if it weren't for me seeking answers and realizing I needed something I was not getting in twelve step  which is very short sighted in trauma. aa can actually exacerbate existing trauma because they are very closed minded and dogmatic about there own ideas. And certain trauma based destructive cycles found me in the confines of living in drug recovery community. Because of many variables that are at work the structure of AA and modern day drug treatment practices have the propensity to create conditions that promote abusive relationships. Although I hate the term narcissist I must say that AA attracts and even facilitates narcissistic abuse on vulnerable people. This is not just my observation. There is a growing community of whistle blowers that have had to deprogram from the brainwashing tactics of the cult like practice of twelve steps. And many many historical narrative s of AA are actually being disputed by people who have researched them. AA had a stranglehold on how we look at addiction but so much evidence is out there since the publication of their archaic text that really disproves what is practiced in AA culture. AA is not open to anything new. That's what makes it dangerous. Trauma in AA is actually made worse because they interpret their members as the problem. They put blame on victims and use fear to propell them into confession to complete strangers with no qualifications to receive potentially traumatic experiences from them. Many people myself included stay stuck in twelve step because they are brainwashed by it. They are told their guys or feelings can't be trusted. The disease model they push pretty gaslights members to think that their minds are their enemies and therefore if they have a thought that isn't in line with the approved literature in AA that is the disease talking and hence they need to dismiss it. I'm sorry if I sound like I have disdain for AA but I definitely don't for its members . I realize that I was once brainwashed by it so I tend to think that way about its members.

I was not familiar with the Elvis Presley song Dr. Mate mentioned.  I found it and I listened to it.  I got to wondering about Elvis' childhood.  He grew up poor, lonely, and bullied. I had never thought about his childhood before.  I just thought that his fame gave him groupies and a schedule where he was going to bed late, drunk or high and getting up early leading to more drug use.  I see now that fame made him rich, but also compounded the problems he already had.  Thank you, Tim and Dr. Mate.  I always learn so much from the interviews.  In one of the interviews I recently listened to,  I learned that the highly sensitive person was the shaman in a traditional society.  I don't feel so crazy now.  Having been told several times, I was too sensitive, I thought there was something wrong with me.  Just that tidbit is so "freeing."  I looked for shamans in my area. Better late than not at all.  I have a good chance of truly getting better now.

When Dr. Gabor MatÃ© says, "We don't respond to the present moment. We respond to the past," he is highlighting the idea that our current behaviors, emotions, and reactions are often influenced by past experiences and traumas rather than being solely a response to the current situation we are facing.  This concept is deeply rooted in his understanding of how early life experiences and traumas shape our psychological and emotional responses. Many of our reactions, coping mechanisms, and even physical health issues can be traced back to unresolved events and emotions from our past, particularly from our childhood.  In this context, he's suggesting that our behaviors and emotions are often triggered by memories and emotions that are stored in our subconscious minds. These triggers can cause us to react in certain ways to situations that may seem unrelated to our past experiences. For example, someone who experienced abandonment as a child might struggle with trust and intimacy in their adult relationships, even if the current partner is trustworthy and reliable.  Dr. MatÃ©'s assertion underscores the need for individuals to delve into their past, explore their childhood experiences and traumas, and work through any unresolved emotions or issues. By doing so, they can gain insight into why they react the way they do in various situations and potentially break free from patterns of behavior that are rooted in the past.  It's important to note that while our past experiences do influence us, they don't determine our entire present or future. With awareness, therapy, and personal growth, individuals can develop the capacity to respond to the present moment in ways that are not solely dictated by their past. This concept is aligned with many therapeutic approaches that focus on understanding and healing past wounds to promote healthier responses to current situations.

Dr. MatÃ© has been part of the movement advocating for the responsible and controlled use of certain psychedelics, such as psilocybin (found in "magic mushrooms") and MDMA (commonly known as ecstasy), in therapeutic settings. Some of the key points he has highlighted include:  Trauma Healing: Dr. MatÃ© believes that psychedelics, when used in a therapeutic context, can potentially help individuals explore and process deeply rooted emotional traumas. These substances may facilitate access to repressed emotions and memories, allowing for a more profound therapeutic experience.  Addiction Treatment: He has also spoken about the potential of psychedelics in treating addiction. Research has shown promising results in using substances like psilocybin in combination with therapy to help individuals overcome substance abuse issues.  Mindfulness and Self-Awareness: Psychedelics may induce altered states of consciousness, which can lead to enhanced self-awareness and mindfulness. This heightened state of awareness can be valuable in therapeutic settings for gaining insights into one's behaviors and thought patterns.  Importance of Context and Integration: Dr. MatÃ© emphasizes the importance of using psychedelics in a controlled and supportive environment. The integration of psychedelic experiences into daily life and ongoing therapy is crucial for deriving lasting benefits.  Caution and Responsible Use: While Dr. MatÃ© acknowledges the potential benefits, he also emphasizes the importance of caution and responsible use of psychedelics. These substances are not without risks and can have adverse effects, especially when used inappropriately or without proper guidance.

[Warning: a long one. Apologies for the essay but this is important stuff]    Alice Miller's The Drama of The Gifted Child is probably one of the most influential and seminal work I've read. In fact, I lent it to a friend who had revealed many of his childhood hardships and trauma but he didn't read it (or not yet) But at least he didn't lose it lol. Not important as I will be ordering another copy which will probably be my third or fourth because having shared it a few times, I always have to have a copy of it in my library.  Another one of her brilliant books also perfectly described my life as well: "For Your Own Good" details the rigid and regimented German pedagogy in which emotions are suppressed and contained in order to maintain a certain kind of social order, compliance, difference to authority and the emotional toll. It takes on the individual. Most especially how those deep-seated repressed anger must be released in some form, which Hitler harnessed and made full use of the scapegoat that was became the Jewish people. A fascinating and important must read. Most especially if you happen to be brought up with these kinds of child rearing protocols, an iron fist in hand, severe forms of physical punishment, etc and emotional distance and a lack of expressing love or tenderness. My father grew up in Germany during WWII and only came to Canada after the war ended as a teenager and I suppose the godsend was that he was a little young to be recruited for the Hitler youth. But he doesn't talk much about those days, stopped speaking German. The moment he came to Canada, wouldn't allow my grandmother to speak it at home when she visited but later she filled me in on her early experiences, Not only with my alcoholic mother after marriage but also the highly deferent fatherland as she would have to stand at the after serving dinner to wait for her husband and the golden boy, that became my father, to start eating. I think it was to ensure that everything was up to their standard or something and would prevent a strong rebuke as she could easily and quickly fix it.  I remember in my early 20s after moving away to New York Cityâ€”pretty much fleeing from my hometown of Vancouverâ€”and reading DotGC with astonishment and while it was 30 years ago, I can remember where it was, remember the place where I devoured most of it: Pier 46 in the West Village and Even remember the time and day and weather when I came to one of its most powerful and meaningful passages, as it basically described my life. I think my jaw stayed on the piers wooden flooring most of the time reading it. Fortunately for NYC in the late '80s going into therapy was a pretty standard practiceâ€” embraced actuallyâ€” in contrast to my hometown which was pretty stodgy and backwards in that regard. It was a decade long journey that both the book, the city, and other positive influences would herald.  I'm not sure if it made me weep or not, but the same sort of sentiment occurs in Good Will hunting when Matt Damon breaks down with his therapist played by Robin Williams after using his typical protective armour, but his therapist is intent on breaking through:: "it's not your fault, it's not your fault... [Will is like WTF, but is softening] .... therapist continue: "it's not your fault....it's not your fault..d.. [and again and again as he starts to reach the core of Will's  demons, the ship on his shoulder etc..... "it's not your fault, it's not your fault....." and on, until Matt Damon breaks down in his arms. That gets me every time. It's usually pretty much sobbing and water works for me. Actually I just need to imagine that scene and repeat those words about 5 or 6 if I ever want a good cry.  Thank you Tim for having such gifted (that means sensitive) guests with so many healing gifts, illustrious and making the world a better..... Dr. MatÃ©, who knowing his story and his loss of family in the Holocaust, has so many reasons to be angry and bitter, but he chose a path of healing and redemption, I regret not being able to see him at his ADHD clinic in Richmond as he was on sabbatical, but almost. Saw his colleague.  who also lives in my hometown and has worked for decades in our beleaguered downtown east side, probably amongst the most miserable and challenging inner city blocks for the marginalized and forgotten, dismissed, ignored and pretty much treated like they're expendable and just like the trash. The home of more than 1000 fentanyl overdose deaths a year, and it's only gotten worse. And this man spent so much of his career dedicated to the marginalized. So his seminal work, "Realm of Hungry Ghosts", a treatise on the roots of addiction, and his work for decades there, an almost brilliant yet simple hypothesis that addiction is the result of trauma. That's it. If we spent some of the billions devoted to the poverty industry and divert to mental health and treatment, that might be a better approach than our complete failure in offering the help these forgotten and disposed of souls need. I've been more fortunate with my own trauma based addiction issues only because I was able to avail myself of what is available, but I have had the support network and so many privileges and access not available to many of these marginalized people with addiction issues,.     Thank God there are wise enough people still that can elucidate such wisdom especially focused on those many of us walk by regularly who aren't fortunate enough to have the familial support and have become shunned and overlooked by those in their former lives. Can you let Dr. MatÃ© know that i would love to have him as my first guest if I ever get around to being a content creator like yourself.

He mentioned the common issue of sacrificing authenticity for attachment. But this seems like another of those popculture biases that creates an awful blind spot: Can we talk about the people who sacrificed attachment to preserve their authenticity? This is like that other one, the 'clichÃ©e' of someone not willing/able to accept help, which creates a blind spot towards awareness of people doing everything they can to seek help but not getting it. This is all perpetuating a very cynical situation where one type of suffering is normalized, where people actually thrive on the pain and then attain better means for healing it, whereas the other type are screwed doubly. Basically one type of misery has mainstream support.  1:59:00 Or maybe vacation with intention is just a further expression of your workaholism, whereas true recreation does not come from balancing unpleasant control experiences with pleasant control experiences but with embracing the true duality, the unstructured as contrast to the structured.  As for the victim-vs-self-empowerment approach, there another dimension of spiritual teaching opens, because if it becomes imbalanced, it can impair actual direct empathy, because then a value judgment might be made on those who self-victimize. The true power is in a decision made to affect someone else's life instead of putting up a wall of doctrine, which can manifest through talk. Often words are mere carrier waves for true caring behind them, or its absence. It is related to people mistaking a healing technique for that which heals. Present a difficult case of need of healing, then offer someone a million dollar for a success story, and see an arguably perverted version of true caring. - But there are and were a few exceptional people (like Bruno GrÃ¶ning) who would give everything they have to offer without subjecting it to the condition of reward. All they are asking for is to receive what they need to fulfill their mission of sharing the best of their abilities. In fact, Bruno GrÃ¶ning had people offer him immense riches for his work, but he rejected, in part from an understanding that it would get in the way of the healing - of that which truly matters. (Although he had the cynical benefit of an ability that would rally enough popular support for his mission to make it sustainable. - And still, eventually he was lawfared to death. Because while he healed many people, very few people could return the favor to him. His mission was inherently sacrificial and he paid the price for it. Although from his viewpoint it was humankind who paid the real price, for not appreciating a gift enough. - Fast forward to Julian Assange, somewhat cynically since his name has gained so much prominence, but it serves the point.)

More over Dr. Gabor MathÃ©Â´s argumentations, even when he formulates a dogma like that ADHD is not a genetical mandatory defect, but a copying-mechanism of an embryonic little yet underdeveloped young human in its motherÂ´s womb, reacting against her stress. There are no culprits here. He follows a benevolent, life-embracing and truly humanistic phenomenological analytic path, which  radically uncovers many of the hardened blind spots of the postpostneurotic-modern human and its society.  But, Dr. Gabor MathÃ© manages to perform this art of analytic psychosocial surgery without harming anyone. There is only to be gained here.  <3  Personally I feel and perceive Dr. MathÃ© as being historically related to R.D.Laing, who by unmasking the concept of "love" in family systems of the 60ies as pure violence (Using game-theory btw.) helped identifying mental illnesses as results of socialy divided minds forced into total personal desperation. But Dr. MathÃ© is at no moment as sad or desperate as Mr. Laing was in its darker moments. Then, wenn he fought to harmonise human violence with his love for humans ("Few books are excusable. Only blackness on a canvas etc." is the opening sentence in his great oeuvre "The politics of experience". Maybe this is by random forces, but I can easily crossread MathÃ© and Laing. It is also to be noted, that MathÃ© does not evoke any pseudospiritual connotations on the overly abused term "hope", since he is obviously more the kind of person who lives by radically accepting existence and has searched for real answers as the modern Buddah that he is. Also he does not chronically regurgitate the overused adoration for the concept of "empathy" (As if such emotion could be forced), as so much mediocre "healers" or lifeless life-coaches throw into the "mindfulness" debate in sheer lack of real effective solutions. No, he obviously went through a universe of work, effort and experience to know how to deliver precious concrete solutions to to fight the ablaze burning phalanx of actual human dilematas and psychological crises  which decorate and infested our current existence. In almost every podcast or workshop Gabor MatÃ© would ask someone: when was the last time you felt anger? The person describes that situation and Gabor asks: how does it make you feel? In other words: what does it mean about you? Then he would challenge that perception with other possible explanations of what happened. Finally Gabor would ask when was the first time you had this perception of not being good enough, coming from childhood. MatÃ© says your brain jumped automatically to that explanation/perception.  So it seems to me that Gabor MatÃ© considers a trigger as a top-down approach where thoughts create an emotion, when in fact itâ€™s stored material which comes up first (that was once in the past created by a perception). Gabor explores other explanations, so questioning the belief, but itâ€™s stored material (that was once created by a perception, but that already happened before). Now itâ€™s already in the body, so isnâ€™t that what you work with? (bottom-up approach of Somatic Experiencing)

Does one person actually feel more than another ?  The word 'sensitive' is ambiguous, with a range of meanings from being easily offended or emotionally hurt to being very compassionate with regard to other people's feelings and beliefs.  Some people are sensitive in both ways, however, it is simply not true that these people feel more than other people.  Rather, it is the case that they value (or OVERVALUE) feelings in general more than they do the actual happiness and well-being of themselves and other people.

You must realize that the metaphysical experience is the direct result of a physical process that you force to occur within your body. Begin by laying down in a safe place. Do a basic meditation to relax your body and clear your mind. Once you are relaxed, you are going to start squeezing and expanding your brain. Your brain is attached to muscles and tendons  let you expand and squeeze it. Bring your focus to your forehead and try squeezing and expanding your frontal lobe. Concentrate and keep trying until you can get it. Once you can feel it moving then move to the center of your brain, (this is where the glands are located, the Eye of RA) and do the same thing. Squeeze then stretch it out, feel it expand as if past your skull, squeeze, expand... After a few minutes move to the back of your brain where the Claustrum is located. This is where the Sacred Oil is produced. Do the same, squeeze, expand over and over. Once you get the hang of it, start doing it in a wave motion from the front to the back. Continue squeezing and expanding repeatedly until you can start to feel the fluids moving, such as mucus running down the back of your throat. Some people, myself included, experience something that sounds and feels like a crust breaking off the outside of your brain, this is normal. The objective is to get your brain working, you have never used it like this before. Once you get the fluids moving you want to push the Oil from the Claustrum in the back of the brain down the back of the spine, down your nervous system and back up the front. Using your back muscles, push the fluid down the back of your spine to the bottom. Squeezing your muscles in your lower area like your buttocks and sphincter. Then start pushing the fluid up the front of your spine. Men as well as women have kegel muscles, use these like a pump. Using your stomach and your chest muscles, continue pushing the fluid up the front of your spine into your brain, pumping the fluid up the front of the nervous system into the Pineal and Pituitary Glands, the Promised Land of Milk and Honey. Continue repeating this pattern, from the front of your brain to the back of your brain, down the back of your spine to the bottom, and up the front of your spine into your brain. Repeat this process as long as you can. When I did this I was not staring at a clock but it felt like an hour. Realistically I would say 15 to 30 minutes. I did it until all of a sudden I couldn't close my eyes! Not even to blink. This lasted for several minutes. At first I thought I broke my brain! Because if you don't, you won't go all the way to the end and meet the Light.  4. If this does not work the first time, try decalcifying your brain for six months and then come back and try again. I put in a reverse osmosis machine under my kitchen sink for $150.00 and I quit using fluoride toothpaste. Fluoride calcifies the pineal gland, which is what we are trying to activate.  5. This last one is a WARNING. Working on yourself is PARAMOUNT beforehand so that you have the best positive experience you can. Also, you need those skills for afterwards. As Gabor Mate says, you need to reconnect with your true feelings, your original self, before the response to trauma distorted the beliefs and reasoning for life and caused more damage. Does anyone know how to do that? It seems to come down to somatic therapies, journaling and meditation. And shrooms??  But are they safe to take, when you are isolated and alone? For awareness have you looked into (negative) core beliefs'? Morty Lefkoe has a list of them on his website(s) e.g. 'I am not good enough'.  They are misinterpretations we make, based on the way we are treated as children, which seem to fit the facts. We then go on to base our other understandings and interpretations of behaviour and situations on the shaky foundations of negative core beliefs. So we then unknowingly create  our own torture.  The solution is to find out what your core beliefs are and to challenge the unhelpful ones.  CBT therapy tries to do that.  About insight, here is a guy on Youtube called Steven Stokes from Australia, who explains in slides the theory of the mental processes in C-PTSD, from childhood onwards.  He calls it something like developmental immaturity. It leads to addictions as coping mechanisms. That is relevant, because he was an addict himself and he now works in a therapy institution. The name of the channel is South Pacific Private. Anyway, see what he has to say, it's very informative, if complicated.

People are always, understandably, confused when I, a grown woman with a child of my own AND a degree in Literature, counts Winnie the Pooh as among my most cherished books.  I have, in a way, always understood why, as a long time sufferer of childhood PTSD.  Also, I have autism on top of it.  But yeah, it makes absolute sense that he brings that book up.  I hope that one day I will feel like that little girl and her army of stuffed Care Bears and colorful ponies are still alive somewhere inside me.   I havenâ€™t gotten there yet, and still find myself crying at the end.  Hell, Iâ€™m in tears just typing this.  That simple little bookâ€¦so profound for me.  As far as Dr Gabor goes - I feel like we have a lot in common, having experienced both deep, layered trauma along with neurodivergence.  I have never had a substance abuse problem myself, my issues have turned into disabling autoimmune diseases, PTSD, major depressive disorder and dissociative disorder.   Basically, severe mental illness that is â€œtreatment resistant.â€  Despite never trying any hallucinogens, Ayahuasca has been on my radar for over a decade and I wonder if it could help in some way.  I donâ€™t know.   I worked so hard and lost everything - I used to work with the elderly and disabled until I became too sick to work.  I am struggling to find something I CAN do.  Regardless, Iâ€™m sending my love to all of you who are here for similar reasons, anyone who may be reading this.  This path we are on is something else and certainly not what we envisioned for ourselves.

About trauma in the womb: In 2014 we treated a liitle 2 year old boy in Kenya. He wasn't walking yet and showed no initiative to do so. Upon further questioning, we found out that the mother went through a traumatic experiencing during pregnancy: She was the first one to find her dead brother, who was killed by another brother during a fight over the ownership of a car. The feeling here, amongst others, is that you are not even safe in your own home and you cannot even trust the people you are closest to. We gave the mother and the boy PC304x, a remedy that resonates with War Trauma and Genocide. Two days later, the boy started to walk around the table, using the tabletop as a support.

Of course what's called ADHD is not genetic but it's not from stress, either. Highly creative people with fast minds think this way naturally. But when it becomes dysfunctional, it's because of physical causes -- a poor diet of dead processed food and no living enzymes, and effects from toxic pharma drugs & shots. The worst thing is to consider it a "disease."

Good and bad are learned concepts. Pain itself is just as neutral as love. Neutral unless viewed from a limited point of view. There's no good and bad outside a limited point of view, and no truth to be found within one. Pain is a mechanism to ensure our survival, so it's good. Romantic relationships are the accidental entanglement of two egos who then become dependent on their established emotional feedback-loop. Technically bad. It all depends on the stance you take. Everything is good and bad, we just never look at things from more than one angle. Because we never question the narrow personality that we've adapted during our upbringing and early adolescence. To question oneself is to be open for truth. Only then is there potential for growth, and only then is there the necessary clarity for telling truth from lie.

I disagree with Mate on a few things, least in his book. His reliance on or at least his deference towards the 12 step model, in particular. It is more harmful than it is helpful, and studies have shown that exposure to it actually worsens most peoples substance (mis)use. (The Sober Truth: Debunking the Bad Science Behind 12-Step Programs and the Rehab Industry by Lance Dodes and Zachary Dodes. Though you can find other sources easily online.)  He does great work, and having said that, we - meaning people with addictions whether they are active or in remission - are not broken or sick people. We are human beings with trauama. We are human beings who overwhelmingly (something like 95 percent) have CHILDHOOD trauma. Those that don't have adulthood trauma. Addiction, whether it is to a substance, videogames, Television, Pornography, Sex, Food, Gambling, or whatever else one can be addicted to (which is pretty much everything) is a trauma response. Why that is so confusing is anathema to me. It's not some spiritual malady. YOU ARE NOT BROKEN. I PROMISE YOU. SOMETHING HAPPENED TO YOU, AND THOUGH SOCIETY MAY DELEGATE THE ROLE OF OUTCAST TO YOU, IT DOES NOT NEGATE THE FACT THAT YOU ARE A HUMAN BEING AND THUS HAVE SUCH GOODNESS AND LOVE INSIDE YOU THAT THOSE YOU KNOW WILL BE SHOCKED WHEN YOU SHOW IT TO THEM!

FYI; in cultures that maintain shamans, the person who is sick or plagued or in need of healing g or spiritual insight DOES NOT consume the toad or vine or mushroom. THE SHAMAN consumes the entheogen, and in that state performs the diagnosis and cure and deliveres advice.  Someone who gives entheogens to others is NOT a shaman. The keeper of the medicine is beholden to the spirit of the medicine, and to administer it appropriately and in keeping with the spirit of medicine. They are in charge of recipes,  dosages, and ritual around the medicine.  Critically they are responsible for gatekeeping the medicine and administering it only to those who need it a d who the medicine approves. A medicine keeper will refuse to give the medicine to someone who it's not right for. Someone who gives  the medicine to anyone is called a drug dealer.  You can think of it as the difference between a doctor of surgery (shaman) a doctor  of pharmacy (medicine keeper) Anyone who claims they are a shaman should be able to enter trance, commune with spirits, and come back with useful information.  Anyone who claims to "have" a shaman - especially when they are describing someone  who will administer  entheogens, should  be considered  at best confused and at worst dangerous.  Let's also add that a medicine man is not a witch doctor. Medicine keeper = Pharmacist  Shamans = Surgeon  Witch Doctor = Oncologist  And last but  ot least, the medicine chooses the patient, not the other way around.  Love the interview,  stay safe.

My dear friend, thank you very much for this wonderful sharing. ANd this is why I'm sharing this here, hoping you 'll read it. There is always a part that is missing for me despite the already very advanced approach and it is the clarity around the method of integration in a mental therapeutic way, which refers classically to psychotherapy. I strongly encourage you two looking at Teal Sawn process called The Completion Process, which is as clear as water and for which I'm so veery grateful because it has the parts that was missing :  Fragmentation is what you're referring to when the child has to choose between Love/Attachhment and his own Truth/Self/gut.  Shadow Work is when you ask yourself 'when was the first time I felt this way?' and you trace back the first traume AND, and this is what's missing in your explanation that is CRUCIAL for the biological shift to happen/change the pattern/heal, is to talk to this part and save him out of the situation he is still stuck : which is literally the definition of trauma ; an unresolved pain.  This is where Parts Work takes place, which is another step of the Completion Process that can be done independently (for example, I just want to know why I have this part that wants to do this and another one that doesn't? It can just be use as a self-inquiry, acquaintance). So you start asking questions to this part as if you were literally in presence of a child/baby (whatever age you went back) in front of you and you are the only one who can rescue this little one. You will try to know as much as you need to take him out of the place of trauma. The great advantage with this technique is that you can do whatever you want since it is in your mind. Imagination is your limit. You can create a safe heaven and whatever saviors you want to involve because, in this space, everything is possible. You, as the adult, guided if necessary, is the one allowing anything to happen.  That is the part that makes all the difference. Changing the story. Healing : which really is experiencing the opposite. When a bone break, to heal is to put the bone back in place and state. Being abandoned is to be saved. And we can to that with this process.  English is not my first language, french is. Your so intense and so insightful, I cannot sit through an entire video...too much processing.  I am excited to see someone else talking about pain on a forum that might be able to help people. I regularly point out how, when a child experiences any variety of pain, there usually is not someone around to "help process" the emotion (or energy)  So the child throws the pain/energy into a black bag called a subconscious and goes on.  They/we develop a lifetime of throw and go and throw and go.  As adults, that black bag can begin to tear and things come out that we don't know what they are or what to do with them....so we call it anxiety and medicate it.  One woman frantically stated "I'm so anxious I cant stand it" when asked what happened she said "my grandkids came over and tore up the whole house."  She was told...your not anxious, you are angry.  She said "Damn right I am!!!"....and that I believe is most anxiety.         We also use the variety of techniques to push down or distract from the multitude of emotions/energy we threw into that black bag.  Going through my own tramatic experience causing me to cry for years and then burying the energy with food, I knew I had to find a way to deal with pain.  I found that writing allows me to transfer the pain/energy to the paper using the right and left hemisphere of the brain.....and burning allows for a true release.   You mentioned EMDR.  Walking naturally causes the eyes to move from right to left.  In walking the mile circle 2-3 times with a friend....I always felt I had a therapy session and didn't know why till ten years later...very basic, very accessible form of EMDR.  I also learned about the tapping technique or Emotional Freedom technique.   I nor the people I know, will never get to the level of therapist you talk about.  I have often wished I could try aouwaska(?).  But I feel I have been blessed to deal with the level of pain I have dealt with. Im guessing I got through about half the pain in my subconscious.  Life is so much better.  Self worth exists and has saved me from some serious individuals who wanted to take advantage.  I know I got more to do and will use the tools I have, but it helps that others have pinpointed the issue of pain. So many people are afraid of it...thinking it will never go away.  Only problem is...it doesn't go away until you deal with it.

I want to make a comment regarding the word "sensitive" as opposed to "gifted". I actually feel both are incorrect words being used to  describe a person. IF you want to say someone is gifted then I think you have to say everyone is gifted and if you want to say that person is not gifted then you have to say no one is gifted. I simply think this is an overused word.  AS you can see it has lost all meaning.  As for sensitive, Tim makes a good point about negative emotional reactions being usually attached to people that are called sensitive. He does not possess that reactionary attitude and yet his friend said he was sensitive. I prefer to use the phrase that u used in it podcast with Russell Brand when you said-- if society accepted that we all have souls, they would not treat each other the way they do.  YOU said it in a slightly better way but I think you will recall that statement.  Piggybacking on that, I would say that people that are considered sensitive by society or even by themselves or their mama simply are still attached to their soul while others have become detached from their soul due to their interactions within their family and/ or within the society in which they live. This leads one to say once again that we are ALL sensitive and we ALL feel but some of us are detached from that while others persevere-- remaining attached to their soul and their sense of feeling their own pain and others' pain. AS you have noted many times in many podcasts, that often leads to a person becoming an addict to drugs etc to dull the pain but some people do persevere with the pain & eschew drugs  and r creative as you noted.  I too like Tim avoided that book due to its title-- THE Gifted Child-- which I don't agree with as it already implies exclusivity which is wrong and harmful to both the person who thinks they're gifted & to the person who thinks they are not gifted. IN all events, it's a harmful label.        I was living in a city that was slowly becoming a  majority of foreign-born children coming with a different language and culture and my neighbors-who were very average, blue-collar people from very average or even less than average backgrounds- decided their son was gifted because he was put in the gifted program which simply meant he understood American culture inside & out and the dominant language used & all the culture's innuendoes due to being born within the dominant language &  the dominant culture into a family that only had one child and babied him to the  extreme. HE was NOT "gifted". HE was NOT particularly "sensitive" but he was immersed in a culture that he was able by osmosis to absorb and consequently perform well on all the little tests they give these very young children to decide if they are "gifted". A highly unfortunate process that they NOW do & which they did NOT do when I was young, thank goodness.  AT that time of my youth,  one of my teachers said we should NOT separate the students into those that want to go to college and those that have absolutely NO desire or ambition or ability to go to college because the child  will NOT understand the full panorama of how people are.  THAT actually is the ONLY thing I remember from that class and the teacher said it ONLY to those of us  lingering after class-talking more to himself than us- but my young self knew instinctively he was right.  THE Mozarts; the Beethovens;the Leonardo Da Vincis are  or course symbols of giftedness-tho often not recognized as such in their time- BUT WE ARE NOT. We individually  have certain proclivities and may be attracted to certain things in life that we love and that we excel in but I do not believe that translates that we are gifted. TO use that word and that concept creates more harm for the individual & the society at large then to simply avoid that word entirely.  Definitely the original title is the best descriptor & is truly inclusive of all mankind because are we not all from time immemorial prisoners of childhood?

I wanted to add....you talk about people becoming disconnected with technology like texting and such. Mate's logic: the mind creates the world, but no, the world creates our minds. So the ancient wisdom got it wrong. Thanks to the power of modern thinking, modern society, we can go beyond that.  This is crude arrogance. Problem: but what created the world? A previous mind, one would suppose, which was created by a previous world. It's an endless regress. The Buddhist understanding is one of beginninglessness. Therefore there is no one to blame, nothing to blame. And in the absence of blame, there's a genuine way forward.  Mate reduces suffering to definite causal childhood experiences, which is also his understanding of politics. It's fallacious, and misunderstands both the Dhammapada and buddhadharma. He claims to provide a means for bringing people in the present moment, but with this materialistic-psychological perspective, he will always be trapped in the peanut gallery of bad analytic thinking, which always brings one to blame, attack and counterattack, accurate critiques, as far as they go, but no real way forward. Except when he forgets this bla bla bla, and connects with his spontaneous compassion, immediate connection with his own heart and others, which is not a product of his faux analysis.

When it comes to suffering, the Buddha nailed it. Of all those exploring the origins of suffering, none went deeper than he did. Using my own language, we shouldn't look at the branches, but go into the roots. The root is identification with a false sense or self, or ego. (I'm not excluding the branches, as they are relevant: such as poverty, socio-economic conditions, parental stress, and so on. I'm only suggesting these considerations don't go sufficiently deep.)   Ever since the child begins acquiring language, he begins developing an ego, separating himself from others and from the environment generally. He (and unquestioningly) identifies himself with his personality, body, the group, the nation. Along with these identifications come comparisons and measurement: how do I compare with others, in terms of intelligence, outward wealth, social position, outward beauty, and so forth. Moreover, with this identification it is "I", the ego, that takes responsibility, that must assert itself among other competing egos. This sense of individuality of course leads to conflict, a sense of failure, incompleteness, that something's "always missing", on which commercialism, advertising, and the economy feeds.   The crazy thing is that this ego doesn't really exist, though the unwavering conviction that it does leads to massive damage, including exploitation and pollution of the environment, from which people feel they're separate. Parents, all of society emphasize your personal identity, as though it were the foundation of all action. Example: "I feel guilty", "I am angry", "I feel guilty about my anger" are all fictions: there is guilt, there is anger, yes, but no "I" that is angry, guilty. This "I"  that feels "I am happy" or "I need to become more responsible", "I need to change" are on a par in a way: for they all strengthen the sense of what isn't really there. If you go the way of this "I", your problems will never end. This confusion is the source of never-ending trouble. This false self, while repressing one thing, or seemingly solving one problem, creates 10 fresh ones, because the false self is by nature incomplete, fragmented, divisive. You're taught to be ambitious, to prove yourself against others, to surpass others, to be special (as opposed to others who aren't really), and this process leads to a great deal of depression, because along the way you get sick, you lose that for which you strove, you lose your abilities - without ever having discovered what you really are.  Beware 99 per cent of self-help books, as they only strengthen a false sense of self.   5 poems here, the first 2 about chaos (suffering), the other 3 about self-realization:  Shattered Mirror  Anonymous One, The mirror once stood still as Your radiant smile. The stars' clarity bowed before Adam's eyes. Then it shattered somehow, and the fragments' guile Started playing out with scheming surprise. Each deemed itself a unique culture and nation; It dreamed forth different faiths and hierarchy; It dreamed forth good and evil; each person's station Competed with another, and the enemy Or one fought against was inevitably born. Someone posted up a flag, and a flag was torn Or burned by someone else; the crusader's mind, Sword-intent, tried converting the equally blind. Much later, there was the democratic crusade, The axis of evil parade and charade. What the axis of evil intimated was not That the good would flower forth, be gloriously brought Into the open, once light had vanquished dark, But only how destitute both sides are of Your spark. The source of chaos and madness is not a foreign kind, But the long-divided, fragmented mind.   The More and Emptiness  Anonymous One, We can trace spiral staircases of ocean waves, Geometries of blue reaching for the sun. Eyes and universe can become good friends; The contact can unfurl order in all we do. If we can embrace that which is prior to thought, Stars will take off their haughty robes and bow; They'll be as loving as leaves are to the bough. But thousands upon thousands of years Have been transcended by only a few Because the More's been master in much that we do. The master has taught us a few things, yes; He may be a friend but is an enemy too, For he builds walls, and therefore emptiness And isolation are; hearts are heavily billed When the mind pursues, pursues, when mind is filled. The More convinces us there is something to become, That without becoming somebody, there's no progress. Yet the More's wife is Irony: mind's made numb, Repetitive, conflicted; She has an attractive dress That shimmers and glitters when She dances, But no gate of heaven is, only emptiness. The striving, striving is only more of the same. Without the heart's stillness, order's only a name.   Everywhere  Anonymous One, I am everywhere, as much a dandelion, tulip, or rose As the most distant galaxy, all of space, and beyond those. I am Your mystery: I am neither Hindu, nor Christian, nor Jew, Though I am blood, bone, tenderness of friends, All the craziness of lovers, and the estranged making amends. I have no identifications, or if Soul Does, it only identifies with the Whole. If what I say weaves nicely with the words of Christian or Jew, Muslim or Sufi, it only does because reflection And stillness of mind have discovered it to be true. And truth does not belong to a culture or faith or what not: A fisherman simply waits on glassy waters and something's caught. Though he has a home and address, wife and friends, Though he loves his time by the fire, his children's play, Though he might even be an assembly's part, He never forgets the sun-hushed invitations of his heart. His real home is nowhere, heart's nakedness. The language of fear and profound loneliness, Helplessness, that makes one want to identify, Has no hold, for truth alone would satisfy.   Meditation  Anonymous One, Sometimes when cranes circle overhead, A person washes dishes with a circling hand. Sometimes when a bear runs and catches a silvery prize, A tennis player finds his perfect stride to the public's cries. Sometimes when a brand new car is first driven out, A bunch of new stars shed their cocoon. Sometimes when green leaves blush with the dawn of June, A virgin overcomes her awkwardness and doubt. Sometimes when it snows in Montreal or Edmonton, The flakes floating down, calm, That means that though the person has never known snow, His mind's calm, as he sits under a palm, While a lake in Vermont evens out to staring trees, And a dragonfly's perched on reed, at her ease. A leaf has fallen and a wind has blown In Africa, and a famous man emits a final moan. It's not quite synchronicity, it's much more: It's perhaps meditation, an awesome whole; It belies individual effort and control.   Amsterdam Park  Anonymous One, The mature bloom of yellow afternoon Waved at us, and we entered Amsterdam park. September spoke softly to beach and sand dune, Passersby, deer, trees, red-berry bushes, till the Moon-Dark Of ourselves and aloneness silenced words, Scattering them as though they were a flock of birds. My friend and I - we walked and walked and some profound, Vast and alien meditation suffused each trail and mound. I could no longer say the rabbit stirred the grass Or deer leapt; any movement that would pass Was rather some anonymous force bending space In infinite ways; the green-glowing beetle was Your Face. We stopped by somewhere and only felt there was no mistake, That we had never been elsewhere or ever could be. I say now that we had come to some water With austere presences, each towering tree, But it was Aliveness before the world began: The horizon and shoreline were arcs, and in between Resounded ruffled echoes, cries from the Nothing-seen.

I love everything Dr. Mate says and the actual conversation of listening and responding going on here. The thread disconnects for me when it comes to psychedelics. There's just too much history with addiction here. Look at what happened to many people in the 60s. It didn't turn out pretty. The problem is you think you need it to continue to have the insights, healings and the intense feelings of love. Many people used it as an escape. What was his definition of addiction? It helps until it doesn't and you keep on using it. One starts thinking they need it. There's better ways to go, non-substance ways. What Dr. Mate discovered can be revealed through pure spiritual experiences, chanting, deep reflection and meditation, and it doesn't have to take 10 years. I chant nam myoho renge kyo, which was the Buddha's last teaching of the Lotus Sutra. The chant purifies the mind and body so that the Buddha's wisdom, which is in all of us, can surface clearly. In my opinion, psychedelics take us to a state of bliss (not nirvana) or a high, which is transient, not transformative or transmutational, and can be risky. When ayahuasca was practiced by the original Amazonian tribes, it was a completely different setting, as Dr. Mate said, a different culture and time. Just because it started way back when doesn't mean it's the best for people. Just because it's an old practice doesn't necessarily make it a good one in the end. There are many things people have done for millennia, including war, rape and pillage. They don't pass the test of time. It puts you in an altered state of mind, not reality. IMO

I read about the British studies of the affects of stress on babies in utero a decade ago and it resonates with me.   I alone, among 6 children in a stable, relatively happy household,  struggled with ADHD in school (in the 60's before anyone knew anything),  terribly afraid of people and had to be dragged into kindergarten, too shy to talk to anyone other than my sisters,  depression hit in my teens,  insecurities continued until middle age.   The cause?  Over exposure to Cortisol due to the stress my mother was under?    My mother birthed her 3rd healthy child 2 months before I was conceived.   So she was caring for an infant during my gestation - AND - simultaneously she was involved in caring for her father, who she loved dearly, who was dying horribly of black lung disease.  He died 2 months after I was born and I was placed in the care of a relative for a few weeks while she was attending to funeral, supporting her mother etc.   I've not wanted to sound corny that I never believed my mother truly loved me but Dr. Mate'  affirms that my irrational fears and insecurities began in utero.

This is fantastic and wonderful...Thank you.  I'm wondering about sensitivity. Dr. Gabor says a sensitive person "feels more"....  I do trust what the doctor is saying.... but I'm struggling a bit with the concept that some are more sensitive than others.  Let's say--for the sake of argument--that two people were born into identical circumstances---(identical, of course, is impossible--but again, let's just say identical for the sake of argument). The reality of "sensitivity" would mean that one individual could be more impacted...affected more deeply by those circumstances. I think that this is true...BUT at the same time I question it....because it would mean that sensitivity is a genetic trait (aka it exists absolutely separate from experience). Are we really born with different levels of sensitivity??? Or...could it be that what we call "sensitivity" is actually just a correlated response/burden/impact of specific struggles and trauma? Perhaps someone who is "more sensitive" simply had a circumstance that created a higher level of struggle and/or suffering. I'm leaning to the latter belief--for one reason---because someone being more sensitive genetically seems to be profoundly difficult to prove---because even if analyzed the behavior/responses/reactions of newborns you could not draw any conclusions about a genetic existence of sensitivity....because that newborn has already experience 9 months in the womb...having experienced unique conditions such as stress of the mother, chaos in terms of the mothers behavior and circumstances; or conversely peacefulness of the mother's mental state and/or circumstances. Having been pregnant myself--I felt/believed on an intuitive level that my every experience and particularly my response and reaction to them directly affected the state and development of my unborn child. I'm just wondering if sensitivity is a "thing" that exists in us (irregardless of experience/circumstances)...or if it is a trait/condition that directly correlates to the level of challenges/difficulties they have experienced. Maybe it doesn't matter either way, but for me it is worth wondering about. Thank you, best regards

The exercise done two hours in was interesting, but what if your frustrations don't come from personal slight. What if I am simply angry about the fact that the job is not done? These emotions exist independent of any assumption about the person doing the job or their perception of me, I just want the job done and it's not materializing. I suppose that what I'm getting at is that anger and frustration don't always seem to have to have deep and profound connection to things that have occurred in the past. In other words the intention of the worker is not the irritant, just the result in general. It doesn't matter that there are 50 million alternate explanations for why the person may not have gotten the work done, just that the work is not done in general. Of course this changes if there is obvious lack of respect behind the reason why the work is not done, but my first emotional response is to the result, not the intent therein. Also I don't necessarily see this as a negative thing because this frustration will serve as a catalyst for finding a solution to the problem.

Gabor's analysis of Tim's response to the tradesman who didn't complete the work is just the fundamental attribution error. Well known in psychology. Basically we attribute other people's behaviour to their character/traits/dispositions and are not aware of the situational factors that apply. Also related to the actor observer effect. Basic social psychology.

worthwhile interview, but I have issues with Dr. Mate's philosophy:  1.  That people are basically good?  Now what, exactly, were the Nazis/Arrow Cross doing to Jews that would convince him of this, not to mention a world that stood by and did nothing (as it'd do again today)? 2.  Indictment of President Trump for his belief that his enemies were out to get him?  They were!  "Just because you're paranoid doesn't mean they're not to get you."--Abba Eban.  This interview evoked Karl Marx for me:  "The philosophers have interpreted the world; the point, however, is to change it."  Why?  Because many people, it seems, are too focused on interpreting themselves, rather than changing themselves.  Take personal responsibility, for God's sake!  Also, Marx's indictment of religion as the "opiate of the masses."  It seems, in our secular society, which gives no credence to the wisdom of religious tradition, suggests that peoples' "religion" IS "opiates;" i.e., any quick fix substitute for the work of getting in touch.  Like grief, the only way around trauma is going through it, which requires hard work; it's painful, but it's the only way.  A religious lifestyle, with strong traditions of modeling correct behavior and thoughts, combined with the collective wisdom of thousands of years of lived experience, would go a long way towards improving a secular society devoid of an informed, wise spirituality.  By avoiding or discounting religion, secularists have effectively thrown out the baby with the bathwater, and then they wonder why so many are so lost.

it is interesting ...every one that testifies about their dmt experiences says they were told to be nicer to their wife ... I have meditated for forty years with and with out guidance ... I have received instruction from zen preists and abbots ... lived and studied at a monestary ...  received instruction at the feet of a lama ... and all the while remained a singular and secular person ... I have consumed a number of pyschodelics ... mushrooms ... lsd ... etc. It was all very absorbing and entertaining at the time ... it wasn't until much later in life that I wound up in therapy with the VA ... I agree with all you say in my way but I live basically by inclination with the poor ... or mentally impoverished ... not such as yourselves who are very much part of the bourgouis and empowered ... your sound to me like the socio-political talking heads on the media who are so far removed from the issues in the street  that their testimony is lost on we the people ... at one point in my life I was down too giving up even coffee I was so straight ... and it was not helpful ... the first releif (psychological) that I ever felt was with my VA therapists ... they encourage me to tell the tales and then they the ask if I feel this way or that about it ... and they are usuaally right on the money ... they know how I feel ... if you think someone who has all the advantages is still traumatized and dealing with it ...  can you imagine what it is like for people who live in the drug ridden streets ... I am traumatized but I can introduce you to someone who can wear my dog tags anytime as a symbol of her journey thru the american nightmare and the massive trauma she has suffered at the hands of her fellow man ... anyway I am hopeful but an entire range of healing modalities are still very illegal in america ... listening to all this discussion is like listening to doctors discuss treatment for themselves that are not available or even illegal for we the people ... what you entertain and then share publically with the larger world lands many people in the streets in jail or abusive (sexually) experiences ... I have since a very young child have entertained out of body experiences ... encountered aliens and ancestors and ascended beings ... and still do ... I have found it all to be a virtual mind  game ... humans entertain a psychology and experience that are as far beyond their ablity to intergrate as astronomy would be to a chimpanzee ... we are ill equipted to understand and integrate circumstances beyond our insight ... I feel for all the folks that have been tramatized by a paper cut giving advice to others who who are living life dismembered in body and mind ... all the metaphysical work works, but meanwhile your shaman, priest, pastor, guru or guide  wants to screw you ??? it is all very interesting ... sorry your mother wasn't perfect but ... maybe she was ... meanwhile we the people live in a culture of ignorance and abuse from the streets to jails to psyche centers to each other ... I am listening to this long presentation ... my people wouldn't be able to listen more than a few minutes ... the average american reads at a fouth grade level and has a thirty sceond attention span ...

huge morsels of wisdom mentioned in here that continue to be huge on my own journey.  - self compassion (instead of self harshness) toward our own suffering.  - metta and loving kindness. wishing ourselves and others well.  - getting back into body awareness  - learning to tune into and trust our own inner guidance - somatic experiencing by peter levine  - yoga (but not 99% of the exercise classes!). but instead the ancient practice (and philosophy) of bringing intentional breathing movement and body awareness as a tool to help facilitate mediation.  this is often what yoga teachers learn about but rarely teach, so only deep yoga practitioners get to understand.   I found it curious how much psychedelic experiences were emphasized without discussion on how these experiences can (and often do) cause more trauma if your nervous system is not stable enough for the intensity of the experience.
My mother still has the hard cover copies of the Winnie the Pooh series ;)

I find the quote Gabor reads, from AH Almost incredible and wonderful.  I also find that it's exactly what God wishes for all of us. People complain that a loving God would not allow pain, nor injustice, yet they don't seem to get, and neither did I for a long time, that he did exactly that, and specifically for you, for he can count every hair on your head, and knows what you desire before you know it. But the choice on how to respond to every hardship is yours. If this was not so, God would be a damaged tyranical dictator. But instead, God loves you so much that he gives you chance after merciful chance to choose the way for your ultimate healing and inner truth. You're His child, and He created you in the womb, and continues to work on you as a potter does with a piece of clay. Every time I read or hear  truly profound words, they all seem essentially to lead directly back to the words of Jesus, who God worked through.

I am very wary of replacing alcohol and cigarettes with psychedelics. There's no quick fix. I am highly appreciative of Gabor saying this. That even after his psychedelic moment of getting it, of feeling the full power of true love, it still took a lot of time after, as he says his wife will testify to. His wife is to me, a remarkable woman.

I deeply question whether it was the experience of taking a psychedelic plant that was what was truly what was transformative in opening to love, or whether feeling connected in a safe environment with people who cared deeply, wasn't in truth the real reason for this opening awareness. That it's not the psychedelic doing it, it's rather the safe environment, and feeling of connectedness that really was the reason. Jesus in only 3 years of his life, through firm, and deeply loving compassion, including miracle healings, did the same for so very, very many without psychedelics. When I talk about Christ, it's not the Christ, and biblical teachings, that many religions have twisted to benefit themselves. I also find it extremely interesting, and wonderful, that it was a complete stranger, who was Christian, that unquestioningly took Gabor in when his mother was so determined to save him. This christian woman kept Gabor safe, until he could be reunited with his mother. Of course his childhood trauma would continue to effect him for years, and years, and probably to some extent still does. God works in mysterious ways.

Hello, Tim, you asked at 1:10:50 about some recommended yoga for people dealing with trauma. Actually there is one - if you are interested, look for a David EmersonÂ´s book called Trauma-sensitive yoga. Good job done there - described a lot about trauma mechanisms and how to understand and deal with them. One of the most important ideas presented in the book was following: nobody can heal your trauma. Because this is not how it works. (And this is, actually, why so many therapies brings nothing or almost nothing to change your life.)    Perfectly explained by Gabor - trauma is not what others did to you, trauma is how you deal with it - you disconnected yourself from your pain, your feelings and your body. Let me say it fully - your trauma is WHAT YOU DID TO YOU YOURSELF. And this is how it could only work. My disconnections couldnÂ´t be repaired by anybody else, than myself.  Trauma-sensitive yoga goes so far, that all presented "exercises" are only "recommendations" and each of them start as an offer "if you want - you can try..." . Why? Your connection with your body needs to be restored and this approach (reminding you again and again "if you want you can") is bringing your competition back. Your competition to feel, to move, to change.  (Sorry if my translation is not that perfect, but I believe if we have the book already in Czech language, youÂ´ll find it easy in English). Thanks a lot, both of you, for your taking time and sharing your ideas and opening new space for people dealing with trauma. Your determination to go deeper and discover the real truth is breathtaking and highly inspirational. Hats off, gentlemen!

So to challenge the idea that getting upset that somebody didn't follow through with something they said they were going to follow through with, necessarily means that we don't respect ourselves really leaves out the possibility that it's okay to get upset when someone doesn't do what they say they're going to do!  Everything is not a lesson of self-reflection. I'm saying that as a psychotherapist. Sometimes things are exactly what they seem and sometimes they aren't.   I suppose if a person reacted by thinking that that person who failed to follow through is irresponsible and they won't use them again, that's different than feeling disrespected. BUT, it can indicate a lack of respect not to do a job you are hired to do. In most workplaces, if you don't do the job you're hired to do, you'll eventually lose your job. No psychotherapy necessary.   I think there's a lesson to be learned. But it's not the lesson that continually gets shoved down most people's throats these days. Everybody is not a mirror to us. There may be a lesson in everything. But that lesson doesn't necessarily mean that everybody reflects us.  Maybe the lesson is that we have the right to expect others to be responsible and if they aren't then they deserve the consequences. We don't need to psychoanalyze ourselves when people don't keep their word. If they don't keep their word, that reflects on them, not us 99.9% of the time.

Â 6GDCÂ  maybe youâ€™re missing something, yesâ€¦Not sure Iâ€™m the one to explain it, but Iâ€™ll give it a shot. One of the brainâ€™s main jobs/functions is to protect us, to ensure our survival. But, our brains canâ€™t tell the difference between real and imagined danger. So if an early experience with a hearing a tiger, in your example, led to a child being taken and thus conditions a response to panic, grab your children and run every time you hear a tiger in the future, then yes that is pure survival. Considered smart, most would say. However,  20 years later youâ€™re in a mall and hear a tiger (letâ€™s say itâ€™s on a TV in an electronics store) and your brain has conditioned you to panic and run and you react as such, youâ€™d probably be viewed as insane because there is no real threat. If youâ€™re paying attention, you probably would panic initially due to your past experience, but youâ€™d have to remind yourself that you are in a different environment so that you donâ€™t overreact. With the kind of trauma theyâ€™re talking about here, I think most of us arenâ€™t really aware of the initial trauma. Maybe a vague recollection or awareness. I donâ€™t have many memories of my childhood, but I know there was trauma. My mother left me as a child, as a result I have an irrational fear that everyone will leave me at some point and until I became aware of this I would often behave in ways that I would not call my most shining moments. And, even with awareness itâ€™s taking practice to control my initial protective and irrational reaction. One of the results of that trauma is constant chatter about how unworthy I am going on in my subconscious. For me casual drinking turned into an addiction because I found that alcohol numbed and quieted those thoughts (albeit temporarily). Now that Iâ€™m seeing all of this, the awareness has allowed me to address the root cause instead of just trying to survive by blocking out the thoughts. Thereâ€™s a lot more to it, of course but your question got me thinking ğŸ˜‰ğŸ˜Š

Doctors Opposing Mutilation FB Page https://www.facebook.com/DoctorsOpposingCircumcision/  Recently a mother-to-be wrote DOC asking whether circumcision pain could be quantified. Our answer follows:  Dear Mrs. McGuire,  You wrote DOC to say that your husband wants to know the exact percent of pain an infant feels during circumcision. Please share the following with him.  There is abundant literature to show that circumcision is painful, that the pain cannot be fully controlled with even the best local anesthetics. The post-operative pain â€“days, a week?--is fully unavoidable. Most circumcisers use nothing for pain. Those who bother apply EMLA, a topical anesthetic, mostly to placate squeamish parents. EMLA is rarely allowed its required â€˜soak-time,â€™ and the effect does not cross over folded layers of skin. EMLA is contra-indicated by the manufacturer for use on mucosal tissue and contraindicated for infants due to the risk of methemoglobanemia, a blood disorder.  Moreover -and this point is important- pain for a newborn comes at a time when his neurological system is â€˜wide-open,â€™ every stimulus keenly and deeply felt. He also has no rational understanding of what is happening to him. It must seem a complete betrayal after nine months of your warmth and comfort.  It is impossible to quantify the resulting pain in raw percentages as your husband asks, due to the subjective nature of pain. All humans are hard-wired differently as to pain tolerance, even at birth.  Even more troubling is the fact, we now know, that pain in infancy has long-term consequences. There is the Taddio study that showed six-month-old circumcised boys are easily identifiable by their dramatic response when immunized. The researchers called the boysâ€™ reactions â€˜an infant analogue of PTSD.â€™  Pain studies done in England have shown that preemies who suffered daily painful 'heel-sticks, blood draws, scalp IV's, etc., have problems with opiate uptake in adulthood. Thus the more cautious and humane neonatal intensive care units (NICU) try to keep all procedures in the NICU carefully vetted for pain inflicted weighed against the diagnostic information derived.  And circumcision, as you surely know, is unnecessary and non-therapeutic.  But I sense another issue here. You husband is likely cut himself or he would not ask questions about pain or hesitate about avoiding circumcision after a close reading of our website, the work of many kindly physicians and nurses.  He may have what we call 'adamant father' syndrome. This manifests itself as a spoken concern for the child that is more likely an unconscious concern for the fatherâ€™s own comfort with an intact son around the house, reminding the father of his loss. It is entirely understandable to want to â€˜match ones son.â€™ There is even a hint of the masculine notion that â€˜my boy will be tough; heâ€™ll be able to take it.â€™  I have to say we believe it is the bravest and kindest of fathers who say, â€œThey did it to me without my permission, but they are not going to do that to my son.â€  We regularly counsel parents where the father agrees to keep the son intact, and then begins to restore his foreskin â€˜non-surgicallyâ€™ so that he and his son will eventually â€˜match.â€™ It is a charming and creative idea we encourage for those adamant fathers who need â€˜comfortâ€™ with the issue.  And finally there is an issue that far exceeds concerns for pain (though those concerns are completely reasonable and compelling on their own.) The Sorrels study (California 2006) and the recent Bossio study in Canada, demonstrate without doubt that circumcision ablates (removes) the most sensitive part of the penis. This has sexual consequences for the manâ€™s entire life. It might not be felt when one is 25 or 30, but the day will come, that mortgage will come due.  We know that young men function despite circumcision, but they might want back the erogenous tissue they lost in infancy as they age. (And sorry for the personal detail, but ask me how I know â€”I am 72 and my nurse wife would dearly like my erogenous tissue back.)  There are other reasons to avoid circumcision:  1) Your son will be born into an English-language world where the practice is in steep and steady decline. Why force him into a minority he canâ€™t escape --and might resent?  2) Why not give him the gift of the body he was born with?  3) Why compromise breastfeeding, or maternal bonding, by injuring him on day two of his life?  4) Why risk a botch â€”too much tissue removed, a lifetime of painful erections, or painful urination due to â€˜meatal stenois,â€™ a urinary opening that is too tight, or worse? These are very common side-effects.  5) Why fuss with wound-care when you can safely ignore his penis for his entire childhood? (A penis requires no special cleaning or care; sterile urine washes it out several times/day; normal secretions fight incoming bacteria.)  6) Why not let him choose for himself? You (and he) have lost nothing if you wait until you can hear his preference.  And he just might (as the intact men I hear from regularly do) THANK YOU from the bottom of his heart for the fact that you gave him the gift of a fully functioning male body when he becomes sexually active in adulthood.  We at DOC (Iâ€™m having breakfast with the president and Board Members today) wish you the best with your son and hope this letter helps you. We are going to the premiere today of the award-winning documentary â€œAmerican Circumcision,â€ that we helped bring to life. It tells the whole story of this curious and controversial practice, rare outside English-speaking countries. You might look for it on Netflicks or Amazon in a few months.  Sincerely,  John V. Geisheker* Director, DOC Seattle  *(a native of New Zealand, where the practice was fully abandoned as non-medical and even unethical in the 1960s. The rate today in my native land? =zero.)

Pain from Circumcision in Infancy Alters the Brain  Research has demonstrated the hormone cortisol, which is associated with stress and pain, spikes during circumcision (Talbert et al., 1976; Gunnar et al., 1981).  Although some believe that babies â€œwonâ€™t rememberâ€ the pain, we now know that the body â€œremembersâ€ as evidenced by studies which demonstrate that circumcised infants are more sensitive to pain later in life (Taddio et al., 1997). I really enjoyed this interview.  This Dr. is a great speaker. It's clear that there is something underneath, something broken, something that causes pain.  For my niece, it has NEVER been addressed... ever. I firmly believe that every addiction is caused by some underlying problem with how the brain functions, and we still refuse to look at this.  Like he says, it isn't even taught in med school -- right now. I am addicted to helping people. I cry every day for those whose lives are unmanageable, but I also obtain a great amount of pleasure from seeing people make even a bit of progress in their trials, cross addicting and depressive behaviors. However, I am old and should be retiring from running what is essentially a halfway house for people who have broken lives. Still, I have not had great success and certainly not so economically. Why do I get up every day? Why do I travel on my own buck to help the Mama to be, who is on bed rest with twins and suffering from hyperemesis gravidarum. I had it to the point of almost dying with my first child and I prayed and figured out how to treat it. So, I had twins to save. They were born 6 weeks later at 3 and 1/2 pounds apiece and only spent a short time  in NICU. Talk about the beauty of my existence! I am an INFJ on the Myers Briggs scale, so I have a rare personality. I sometimes test out INFP, mostly when I am introverting and running from my own childhood pain. Talk about sensitive! And I am a writer, poet, a musical drama writer, an actress...I have had a fascinating life. I just wish I wouldn't spend so much time weeping for the pain that is my own and others or the for the joy of helping make something beautiful happen in others' lives. Â @aaronjsolomonÂ    (Sorry for the late reply, I guess I missed the notification) > "Perhaps the doctor should go through his own exercise while examining his disgust for Donald Trump and his supporters. "  I agree. I would wager he probably does do that in periods of introspection, maybe specifically for Trump, or maybe more generally reconsidering views he has internalised. I don't think he mentioned or expressed feelings of digust, and he definitely didn't say anything about Trump's supporters.  > "In the meantime, I'm not inclined to take spiritual instruction from a person so obviously uninterested in following his own teachings."  That is just a simple, short exercise, that you don't have to take anyhting away from - not really specific spiritual instruction.  Also, I think you're setting an unrealistic expecatation on him (any other teacher, or person even) to be impeccable in what he does and says, to not have any mishaps, to perfectly and consistently do everything in accordance to what he's saying. People are imperfect. I don't think you'll find a single person/teacher, however brilliant they may be, that will be perfect and whose actions will be in perfect accordance to what they say. You set an ideal to which you aspire, you accept that you won't achieve it 100%.  And the fact that you didn't completely achieve it, and that you made mistakes along the way, doesn't make that ideal invalid.  Ideas are separable from, and can be justified without, the private actions and struggles of the person espousing them.  I think you use his (perceived) failure to hold by his teachings 100% to then justify your complete dismisal of him, even though the real reason is you just got offended by him having a disparaging view of Trump. It's not acceptable to you that Gabor might make a comment regarding the statements and actions (possibly misrepresenting those, I'm not saying Gabor was right) of a political figure you care about and also at the same time have useful, correct ideas in a different domain (psychology, therapy). That's not a rational view that you would hold if the political figure in question was somebody that wasn't important to you.  But because it was Trump, and because you were transitively offended as (I'm guessing) his supporter, in your eyes Gabor had to lose all credibility, completely. All his work became invalid just because of that.  I don't think that's not an objective assessment - I think there's ego defensively tainting the interpretation of an objective situation. incredible interview. this is how social workers view and understand childhood and physiological/psychological trauma. if any of you are fascinated by early childhood experiences (beginning in the womb) and how they impact a human neurobiologically, look up Dr. Bruce Perry's Neurosequential Model of Therapeutics.
