When we discuss truth as ideas in 2020, is proof how corrupted the medical profession is. Psychology, fortunately, is not a profession.
Essential

Knowing that the early conditioning & programming (that's largely on a subconscious level) of our young brain & the relationships with the adults around us early on is where trauma often originated can help because once you identify where (for example) feeling unvalued, unsafe, unloved or fearful etc. comes from, why you may think & feel the way you do, why some things cause us to react as we do, why you shut down when you feel hurt.... just knowing these things THEN lets us address & work on using new tools, skills to make conscious decisions daily to choose to make different choices, we can choose to stop believing the old story of ourselves we held & start telling ourselves a different more empowering, more compassionate story to understand ourselves with compassion as we work on eventually reprogramming our subconscious to be fully aware of or beliefs , choices & how we talk to ourselves inside 24  hours a day.     We can learn coping mechanisms that ARE USEFUL beneficial in place of the more self destructive habits we may have used in the past. Day by day, by exercising kindness to ourselves you can teach yourself (or reprogram your brain's circuitry) to react differently with more healthy functional reactions to the painful things we might face       I made more progress on battling lifelong depression in 2011 when I realized acceptance was the key to progress & change for me. (Acceptance; defined as; ability to sit with reality, with my real feelings & accept them as they ARE, allow them to BE for awhile even if it hurts right then, to be authentically me & not just try to bury my feelings or thoughts, deny them or not have to feel them.) That was the key to changing everything about how I viewed & felt about life.       Acceptance of all things, that they are what THEY ARE, that you won't die if you allow yourself to feel it, first lets us release the tension on the mind if you 're fighting what you feel all the time. 2nd; Often you'll decide you don't care that much about something then you CHOOSE to let it go...3rd; I learned tools to use to get through the really painful feelings & let them out , instead of trying to dull the pain temporarily, in harmfu ways. 4th; I let go of the old coping mechanisms I'd learned to use as a child, since they were not helping me as an adult. 5th; As issues came up from my past then, I started forgiving myself for anything I'd been holding against myself & I started to love myself, to feel compassion for the hurt chid inside who needed someone to acknowledge she'd been hurt, especially for myself to say it, admt it & to grieve what I'd lost in childhood or not had.      A load of resentment I'd felt towards others & towards myself lifted bit by bit.  I had harmed myself numerous times in my life, since age 13, but since I learned acceptance & to stop judging everyone AND myself I've  stopped hurting ME, realizing I'm the last person I should add MORE pain to when I'm already hurting so I started learning better methods of self soothing, how to ride out a horrible day, ya know?  I realized it's healthy & helpful to show enough strength to let myself reach out to others to receive comfort when I need it.       I learned to speak my pain when others hurt me, instead of shoving it down, continuing to suffer, acting like I am fine. You can only act for so long,,, you must look inside to find & work on healing, repairing whatever was harmed in your childhood. Our brains are very malleable, trainable and fixable....set yourself free it is possible.(It is a process, but you can feel better each week instead of staying stuck in one place.)

Tim - on the issue of your sensitivity; My experience has suggested to me that all of us have a significant tendency to take our own features as baseline, or norm, and then measure those features as we witness them in others against our own; assuming ours is the norm, and theirs is stronger or weaker than ours. I think this seems the natural method, because our own level is the most readily available scale we have to us, so we just run to it. We start out this way in early childhood, when it's done subconsciously; then we do it continuously and habitually until it becomes germaine to the way we assemble our world view. Once I recognized this, I became aware that now I have to find the yardsticks externally. This is the only way to be fair with ourselves in the process of recognizing, accepting, and becoming comfortable taking credit for our natural gifts. If you've spent a lot of your life's attention building up your weak areas, it can feel uncomfortable accepting praise for those gifts, because your focus has mainly been on weakness, and we tend to become comfortable acknowledging our weaknesses, and when someone praises us for a strength, it's the last thing we expect, and we  don't have much experience in responding.

In all I listened to today, the thing that got to me is that the knowledge you gained, can be nothing but a beautiful memory if not continuously practiced.  He said nothing that was new to me, my shamanic experiences began in childhood, I was reading Freud in my early teens, had my first kundalini experience in my 20s, but over the last 30 years, I became a carer and in order to achieve this role, I had to die.  My mother, the last person dependent on me, died last October.  I'm free, but now I am lost, I don't know anymore what I like or don't like, how to go out with people, I am am starting life all over again, carrying a lifetime of trauma.  I have gone into crisis mode, seen a counsellor, who has led me to seek treatment from trauma informed therapists.  Some are spiritually aware people.  However, still, been here, done that, seen shrinks before, done things before, but they worked only a little at best and whatever I gained, I lost.  The psychiatrist I saw, wants me to undergo a three week inpatient treatment which uses yoga, emdr, etc, for healing.  I wasn't going to do it. After hearing that phrase by Gabor though, I think I will go.  It's not enough to know, you have to live that knowledge, and preferably in community or your knowledge, experiences and even your sense of 'I' is nothing but a memory.  Cool. Performing - to create something different/external to them, that feels better than how they feel inside.   Though when they close off that performance, they're left with how they feel.  Almost to escape how they feel, they go out to perform, to keep their mind on something different than what hurts them, something that stimulates them, something that brings them joy, something that they feel will help what troubles them, not be there to trouble others, because they don't want any other to have to feel the pain they have felt, that they still feel when they take their eye of their counter triggers for what saddens them.  I cried whilst typing this.  Whilst I find all of the above to be true. I have since learned that happiness is a choice, a default or premise mental and heart state. We have to choose what we want thoughts and feelings to compound with.   If we allow external scenarios to influence us to be sad, and if given the opportunity, to saturate your entirety with sadness, every negative then compounds on this, building a wall of hurt with loose bricks wavering, giving the feeling that a collapse is coming.   Leaving you to scatter and scale the wall to push and shove, to keep these wavering bricks in. You may get to a state where more are coming out than you can keep in, and if you've been holding yourself back from reaching out to ask for help, this is the time to allow and accept that no one achieves anything alone.  Once we realise that we want to be happy, that we want our premise thought and feeling to be that of happiness, then from here we can become that, and we can become that straight away.   Some may have more groundwork to do, and so there will be more curves to come around. And by groundwork what is meant is the asking and answering of certain questions.   A good starting question is;   Q: what is the MVP of my happiness?   I found it helpful to separate ourselves from others, by asking this question inwardly for me only, and again externally for others I care about besides me.  A good following question is;   Q: What is in my control and what is not?  With the realisation that I can only control me, and I can only influence others. If I focus on what is not in my control, I am focusing on what I can do nothing about, and so I am tormenting myself, which often is a go to for when we want to feel self pity, when we want to give in or when we want others to see us in so much pain that they will feel obliged to help or to change their behaviour (if it is this that hurts you).  Pity state behaviours form a dependent state. And if you are not receiving the help you need from dishing out these ques, from those you are prompting to act not caring or not feeling capable of being of any help, or from simply not interpreting what you are trying to convey...  developing a habitual pattern of dependence, dependence of assistance that you are not receiving will leave you there where wounds are likely to widen the longer you stay there.  There's more to convey, though Im supposed to be writing a critical review, so best get to the activities allow for me to skip along the stepping stones of happiness.

First time listening Tim's podcast. Brilliant interviewer work. I know from my personal history and professional experience that conversations with deeply inter-disciplinary people (and open, creative people in general) can be tricky : they go different places at the same time, especially when those people are both plural in their inspiration and verbal. Here Gabor goes these different places, tackle many different subjects at the same time, so as the linear conversation unfolded I was like (at several moments) : "Damn, that's an interesting thought/example he offers, too bad that the conversation went passed it..." And YET at multiple times Tim managed to take notes along the way, go back to a certain point of the discussion. He never loses the thread. That is an amazing journalistic work. Bravo !

A good example of an abusive form of this is the following. Imagine you know someone and they are working their ass off, they've become too old and its taking a toll on their health, what a machiavelian might do is tell that person that they look like shit. What does this achieve? It jolts the unconscious human being (unconscious of their own errors) that things must change, and you do this by attacking the ego of the person.   The idea is that they will start asking themselves, do I really look like shit? Should I perhaps take it more easy and be less stressed? Some people have told me that I'm a very anxious person at times but I never believed them, and here a completely unrelated person is strengthening the comments of the previous. The person then realizes that perhaps there is something to this and begins to look for ways to manage their stress levels, they become more conscious of what their body is telling them.

Around 36:35: "She never gave me a good reason to learn the alphabet." I'd caution against the ruinous work of nostalgia. Of course, I don't want to speculate about what kind of child you were, or your experiences. However, I will say: I work with troubled youth, and I currently work with a kindergartner who constantly asks for reasons why he should do x, y, z. I've always been a hyper-rationalist by nature, and I've always found the authoritarian nature of education irritating, so I give the best reasons I can think of and try to calmly explain why it's in his best interest to learn math, spelling, self-control, etc. None of it computes because often children aren't genuinely searching for an objective reason why they should do x, y, z. Rather, they know no reason will be given and that is the excuse to engage in all kinds of escape behaviors. Any thoughts?

Living here in the NW Amazon where yagÃ© is made from the bark of ayahuasca -(Banisteriopsis caapi) which contains the MAOi and the chaliponga leaf (Diplopterys cabrerana) which contains the DMT plus additional tryptamines, so it is a different experience than the chakruna leaf (Pychotria viridis) that Tim mentioned. The Shamans here are called Taitas and they adjust the ratio of the 2 plants, so the drink varies (B.caapi:D.cabrerana). There are different subspecies of B. caapi which affects the type of experience (visual, auditory, physical). You will look at plants very differently the next day with respect and a little fear of their power over you if you are honest. Proper diet and mental preparation before with an intention/goal/question is important as well as set and setting and a good Taita.

Does sensitivity really magnify the pain we have? Or the lack of experiencing a stimulus in life where certain sensitivities exist or sensitivities are involved, that makes it feels more painful than ever?   Your sensitivity depends on the frequency of your experience to a certain stimuli. Like for example: if you keep on using your fingers for playing the guitar you develop callouses on your finger tips. And so it will be lesser and lesser sensitive to pain while  playing with the strings on bear fingers than it was before because of the callouses that becomes a protective covering over the tip of your fingers from a stimuli. Your sensitivity becomes less and less with higher frequency of experiencing a stimuli. Then you begin to be more skilled or creative in playing as you become less sensitive to pain that you can ignore it, so you can focus on the music being created like you can begin to appreciate a tapestry being created than the chaos you see behind while weaving it.   Some of us people just go through life thinking we can just cherry pick the easy and the shortcuts and the joys of it all without suffering. But life is not like that at all. We either go thru life or not. With plenty of both joys and sufferings or none at all. Sometimes we are self-medicating pain or trying to not feel the pain and we donâ€™t see how we are deceiving  ourselves. Sometimes we donâ€™t see that the only way out is to experience that pain so we are through with it and get to that other side where we are supposed to be/where we desire/where we are called to be.   Be it with suffering and  joy, life goes on. In life we either keep going or stop. As if we can stop life. The moment we try to stop thinking we got everything  under control, life drags us anyways. And so life feels like everything is out of control. And thatâ€™s when everything becomes painful.   Life goes on until it doesnâ€™t anymore. As we live, the question is, do we keep playing with the guitar or do we stop playing. If we stop, callouses begins to come off. And the next time we play again, our fingers will be as sensitive to pain as it was the first time we played the guitar.   Iâ€™m not for people who goes finding every pain that exists out their, but Iâ€™m for facing the ones that is in front of you. It didnâ€™t happen the other way coz it didnâ€™t. Your facing the pain in-front of you coz you have to. Youâ€™ll never see the purpose of that pain until you go through it. And if you have God, youâ€™re only promised to go thru pain and life victorious in His guidance.   Some people knows the principle in life and they just keep going and facing life braving through all its joys and itâ€™s sufferings coz they know that when they stop, itâ€™ll be more unbearable. Itâ€™s when we stop that pain stays painful. Itâ€™s when we stop that pain stay stuck and the same like a stone remain unturned.

I love both of these guys and the very human dialogue the interviewer has with MatÃ©, but I feel a bit suspicious and at the very least betrayed that diet isn't factored in here. MatÃ© mentions the traditional preparation for ayahuasca, which is basically a fast. Ask any culture around the world what it means to not eat meat or dairy products, and they'll tell you it's a spiritual fast. It's really irresponsible for Dr. MatÃ© to not mention that veganism shouldn't be a lifestyle, but it seems he's suffering the same blindness his colleagues suffer when they don't take trauma into account as such a huge factor - he's not taking diet into account. We're eating all of these antinutrients and pro-inflammatory foods as one kind of coping mechanism. But just like growing up in a community full of alcoholics or drug addicts, this form of self abuse is normalised and even seen as a healthy life choice. Vegetables, grains, and seeds, are poisons. Some are beneficial as a form of medicine (such as during a fast), but we live in a culture here in the West that glorifies these medicines as our saviours which must be eaten EVERY DAY. A culture you don't find in most other places in the world where, by the way, people live healthier and longer lives.

Baby struggles for breath after circumcision http://youtu.be/zHW930zGdNA   Vomiting It was my sad task to publish a case report about a baby who experienced severe vomiting after being circumcised. Following the vomiting spell, the baby stopped breathing and had to be hospitalized for five days so that he could receive intravenous antibiotics. Needless to say, this never would have occurred had the baby been protected from circumcision. Infants respond to the pain of circumcision by screaming, just as we would if someone slowly crushed and cut off part of our sex organs without anesthetic. When the crying is especially intense, the baby may swallow air. Then, when the mother tries to soothe her baby by feeding him, it may lead to vomiting, followed by apnea.  Apnea (Stopped Breathing) Apnea is the temporary cessation of breathing. The pain of circumcision is so severe that some babies stop breathing during the surgery. In an important study on the pain of circumcision published in The Journal of the American Medical Association, researchers discovered that serious complications occurred during circumcision. One infant experienced the same level of extreme distress as all the others in the study, but two and a half minutes after the conclusion of the surgery, the baby developed an abnormal posture, stopped breathing, and suffered projectile vomiting even though he had been denied food for more than three hours before the surgery. Another baby experienced a choking spell and stopped breathing three and a half minutes after the surgery. The researchers noticed these serious complications because they were looking for them. One wonders how many babies suffer without anyone taking notice or caring, or even thinking there is anything wrong with projectile vomiting, choking, or cessation of breathing. Rupture of internal organs Circumcision is so traumatic, painful, and frightening that it literally terrorizes the baby. Some babies have suffered extreme reactions to this experience that few adults could ever imagine possible. Rupture of the Lung The medical literature details cases of circumcised babies whose lungs have burst as a result of intense crying. In one case, at Georgetown University School of Medicine, a fifteen-day-old baby with severe respiratory distress was circumcised. He turned blue, started breathing frantically, and cried incessantly. Finally, doctors discovered that the crying had caused the baby's right lung to burst. A drainage tube was inserted and the baby was hospitalized for nineteen days. Blood Clots in the Lung A case of life-threatening blood clots in the lung was reported following adult circumcision.  Heart Damage The serious injury that circumcision can cause to other parts of the body is made clear in reports of babies whose hearts were damaged as a result of circumcision . In one case from Rochester, New York, a newborn baby was circumcised in the delivery room, even though the American Academy of Pediatricians has condemned this practice. The baby immediately turned blue, experienced grunting respirations, his temperature dropped to a dangerous level, and his heart muscle was damaged. This baby miraculously survived, but spent eleven days in the intensive care unit of the hospital. In another published report, four babies who were hospitalized following circumcision turned blue, were lifeless, had elevated heartbeats, frantic breathing, grunting, and extremely poor breathing. The liver was enlarged in three of the babies, and all babies showed signs of acute heart failure, enlarged heart, and fluid in the lungs. All four babies had been circumcised by the same circumciser, who had tried to controll the bleeding with epinephrine solution. The doctors who fought to save the lives of these babies believe that the drug may have induced the chain of events that nearly killed these innocent babies. Then this:  The agony and terror of circumcision have lasting, measurable effects on the brain, physically altering it forever  Epigenetics and Child Development: How Childrenâ€™s Experiences Affect Their Genes  https://developingchild.harvard.edu/resources/what-is-epigenetics-and-how-does-it-relate-to-child-development/  Although frequently misunderstood, adverse fetal and early childhood experiences canâ€”and doâ€”lead to physical and chemical changes in the brain that can last a lifetime.  Injurious experiences, such as malnutrition, exposure to chemical toxins or drugs, and toxic stress before birth or in early childhood are not â€œforgotten,â€ but rather are built into the architecture of the developing brain through the epigenome. The â€œbiological memoriesâ€ associated with these epigenetic changes can affect multiple organ systems and increase the risk not only for poor physical and mental health outcomes but also for impairments in future learning capacity and behavior.  Childhood Trauma Permanently Scars Brain, And Boosts Likelihood Of Depression  https://mavenroundtable.io/theintellectualist/science/childhood-trauma-permanently-scars-brain-and-boosts-likelihood-of-depression-XvpPL8thIUaZgfr1B4JhcQ/?fbclid=IwAR0PN7NpgwZAY4uhdWWwQ2z1o2pkTrMfjFrJQOipTiOzyHP71aPChkMzHXY   Stress and trauma in earliest years linked to reduced hippocampal volume in adolescence  â€œThese findings tell us that there may be a â€˜sensitive periodâ€™ in which stress is more likely to affect the development of the hippocampus, which is connected to learning, memory and mood,â€ said lead author Kathryn L. Humphreys, assistant professor of psychology at Vanderbilt. â€œGiven that the hippocampus undergoes rapid changes in the first years of life, the effects of stressful experiences during this period, even those the child doesnâ€™t remember, may be particularly important in understanding the development of this region of the brain.â€  https://news.vanderbilt.edu/2018/12/19/stress-and-trauma-in-earliest-years-linked-to-reduced-hippocampal-volume-in-adolescence/  http://www.kathrynhumphreys.com/   Dorsal Anterior Cingulate Thickness Is Related to Alexithymia in Childhood Trauma-Related PTSD  https://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0139807  Abstract  Alexithymia, or â€œno words for feelingsâ€, is highly prevalent in samples with childhood maltreatment and posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD). The dorsal anterior cingulate cortex (dACC) has been identified as a key region involved in alexithymia, early life trauma, and PTSD.  Functional alterations in the dACC also have been associated with alexithymia in PTSD. This study examined whether dACC morphology is a neural correlate of alexithymia in child maltreatment-related PTSD.  Sixteen adults with PTSD and a history of childhood sexual abuse, physical abuse, or exposure to domestic violence, and 24 healthy controls (HC) completed the Toronto Alexithymia Scale 20 (TASâ€“20) and underwent magnetic resonance imaging.  Cortical thickness of the dACC was measured using FreeSurfer, and values were correlated with TASâ€“20 scores, controlling for sex and age, in both groups. Average TASâ€“20 score was significantly higher in the PTSD than the HC group. TASâ€“20 scores were significantly positively associated with dACC thickness only in the PTSD group.  This association was strongest in the left hemisphere and for TASâ€“20 subscales that assess difficulty identifying and describing feelings. We found that increasing dACC gray matter thickness is a neural correlate of greater alexithymia in the context of PTSD with childhood maltreatment. While findings are correlational, they motivate further inquiry into the relationships between childhood adversity, emotional awareness and expression, and dACC morphologic development in trauma-related psychopathology.   In the human brain, the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) is the frontal part of the cingulate cortex that resembles a "collar" surrounding the frontal part of the corpus callosum. It consists of Brodmann areas 24, 32, and 33.  It appears to play a role in a wide variety of autonomic functions, such as regulating blood pressure and heart rate.[citation needed]  It is also involved in certain higher-level functions, such as attention allocation,[1] reward anticipation, decision-making,[2] ethics and morality,[3] impulse control (e.g. performance monitoring and error detection),[4] and emotion.[5][6]  Stress and trauma in earliest years linked to reduced hippocampal volume in adolescence  https://news.vanderbilt.edu/2018/12/19/stress-and-trauma-in-earliest-years-linked-to-reduced-hippocampal-volume-in-adolescence/?fbclid=IwAR0VaWVlSPKRL_CCuVOxMiNx08jKrsCOmUQ3pmKR64ZogLs_P8x03YAiTSs  CHILDHOOD MALTREATMENT PREDICTS REDUCED INHIBITIONâ€RELATED ACTIVITY IN THE ROSTRAL ANTERIOR CINGULATE IN PTSD, BUT NOT TRAUMAâ€EXPOSED CONTROLS  https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/da.22506  Findings highlight individual differences in neural function following childhood trauma, and point to inhibitionâ€related activation in rostral ACC as a risk factor for PTSD.  Early Life Stress and Morphometry of the Adult Anterior Cingulate Cortex and Caudate Nuclei  https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S0006322306001405  Background Early life stress (ELS) is linked to adult psychopathology and may contribute to long-term brain alterations, as suggested by studies of women who suffered childhood sexual abuse. We examine whether reported adverse ELS defined as stressful and/or traumatic adverse childhood events (ACEs) is associated with smaller limbic and basal ganglia volumes.  Conclusions Reported ELS is associated with smaller ACC and caudate volumes, but not the hippocampal or amygdala volumes. The reasons for these brain effects are not entirely clear, but may reflect the influence of early stress and traumatic events on the developing brain.   Childhood Trauma Exposure Disrupts the Automatic Regulation of Emotional Processing  https://www.nature.com/articles/npp2014311  Results showed that trauma-exposed youth failed to dampen dorsolateral prefrontal cortex activity and engage amygdalaâ€“pregenual cingulate inhibitory circuitry during the regulation of emotional conflict, and were less able to regulate emotional conflict. In addition, trauma-exposed youth showed greater conflict-related amygdala reactivity that was associated with diminished levels of trait reward sensitivity. These data point to a trauma-related deficit in automatic regulation of emotional processing, and increase in sensitivity to emotional conflict in neural systems implicated in threat detection. Aberrant amygdala response to emotional conflict was related to diminished reward sensitivity that is emerging as a critical stress-susceptibility trait that may contribute to the emergence of mental illness during adolescence. These results suggest that deficits in conflict regulation for emotional material may underlie heightened risk for psychopathology in individuals that endure early-life trauma.   ACE What are ACE? Stop Abuse Campaign  https://stopabusecampaign.org/faq-the-ace-study/what-are-adverse-childhood-experiences-aces/   Adverse Childhood Experiences Psychology  https://www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/childabuseandneglect/acestudy/index.html?CDC_AA_refVal=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.cdc.gov%2Fviolenceprevention%2Facestudy%2Findex.html   IA's ACEs quiz includes genital cutting. http://adversechildhoodexperiences.net

When it comes to property and human capital, our postmodern society is wealthier than ever. In terms of social capital, we are slowly inching toward the poverty line, metaphorically speaking. â€œSocial capital,â€ which seems to be declining at an alarming rate, refers to the social networks of relationships among people who live in a particular society and the norms of reciprocity, trust, and cooperation to which those networks give rise. Social Capital Theory posits that our lives are made more productive with social ties. Just as we have basic needs for food, water and shelter, the need for social connection is crucial to our well-being. Sadly, as our communities are unraveling, Americans are becoming more isolated and disengaged than ever before.  The weakening of community networks didnâ€™t just occur overnight  Since the 1980s, the percentage of American adults who report being lonely has doubled from 20 percent to 40 percent. More than a quarter of the population lives alone, and marriage rates and number of kids per household are dropping. According to researchers, formal group membership in professional and local community organizations has declined by 10â€“20 percent over the last five decades. Participation in social groups has been on a downward slope for years and it only appears to continue today.  As our civic engagement declines, so too does our civil engagement. Not surprisingly, recent analyses have suggested that widespread smartphone use has diminished the quality of our interpersonal exchanges. It has become acceptable to ignore texts and emails. If an invitation or even a salutation to a friend was extended in person, and the response was no response, this would be considered rude at the very least. But today, with texting and emailing becoming our primary modes of communication, this type of dismissive behavior has become the norm. And norms are what shape societies.  What is driving the trend toward isolation?  This is no one single culprit responsible for Americaâ€™s disengagement. A multitude of contributing forces have given rise to our current state. In his book Bowling Alone: The Collapse and Revival of American Community, Robert Putnam attempts to solve the puzzle. â€œPostwar generations,â€ he writes, â€œare simply less community-oriented than their parents and grandparentsâ€”more materialistic, more cynical and less politically interested.â€ Drawing from research, Putnam lays out some of the most significant factors driving our social disconnectedness.  Changes in family structure  Families are spending less time together today than in previous generations. Over the last 30 years, family dinners and conversation declined more than 30 percent, which, according to the American College of Pediatricians, has a significant impact on children as they grow up. Children learn socialization through live interaction with adults, and when this is compromised, language delays can result. At one time, the classroom may have offered a satisfactory substitute to a lack of interaction at home. However, when the pressure to achieve at a high academic level in competition with peers takes priority, another area of socialization is lost.  article continues after advertisement  Suburban sprawl  As many city dwellers began fleeing to the suburbs, farther apart from our neighbors, we traded tight communities for vastâ€”yet mostly emptyâ€”spaces and empty voids we seek to fill with food, shopping, or television. Commutes are longer, usually spent alone in a car, draining time and energy and with them the inclination to participate in social or community groups.  Misguided priorities  Another factor Putnam and other researchers blame for our increasing social disengagement is misguided priorities. Sociologist Philip Slater, author of The Pursuit of Loneliness, writes that the root of disconnection in America is â€œthe collective obsession with the success of the individual.â€ Though written more than 40 years ago, it appears not much has changed since. Money and status are increasingly prioritized, sometimes at the expense of the quality of our relationships. We were brought up in a culture that tells us that the more money we make, the more things we accumulate, the better title and fancier job we have, the happier we will be. However, the science tells us otherwise.  Technology  One of the biggest culprits of social isolation and disengagement, according to Putnam, is the â€œprivatization of leisure time.â€ Technology and mass media have become the medium of choice through which many of us spend our free timeâ€”usually alone. This is sometimes true even when we are in the same room. The phrase alone together has become such a ubiquitous cultural reference that it is now the title of a television show.  article continues after advertisement  The internet offers a wonderful alternative to stay connected for those who may be confined to the home due to health or age-related factors. The use of Skype and other VOIPs, for example, has made it easier for friends and families living on opposite sides of the world to keep in touch. Technology becomes detrimental when it is used as a primary form of communication, which, sadly, seems to be the direction in which we are headed. Although we cannot only blame modern technology, it has certainly made an already growing problem even worse.  Consequences of our disengagement  As multitudinous as the causes of social isolation and disengagement are, so too are the consequences. Higher rates of crime and violence, competitiveness, inequality, addiction and loneliness are some, to name a few. Those who experience chronic loneliness are at a significantly greater risk for developing the conditions that lead to premature death such as cardiovascular disease, stroke, altered immune systems, and depression.  It is important to note the difference between loneliness and social isolation. Although they often co-occur, one does not necessarily beget the other. Loneliness is a subjective feeling of distress, arising when social connections are perceived to be inadequate or unfulfilling. Social isolation is the absence of meaningful social relationships. It is possible to be isolated but not feel lonely, and vice versa.  Public Health Implications  Nonetheless, self-reported feelings of loneliness and the objective state of being socially isolated have negative effects on our health. There is compelling evidence that both are associated with poorer physical, mental and emotional well-being. So much so that the American Psychological Association (APA) is calling for social connection to be made a public health priority in the US. Loneliness is as important a risk factor for premature death as obesity and smoking. The World Health Organization (WHO) lists â€œsocial support networksâ€ as a determinant of health. A sense of isolation or social rejection, researchers say, disrupts our cognitive abilities and our immune system, making us more susceptible to disease. Essentially, our disconnection is making us sicker and more addicted and our lives emptier.  article continues after advertisement  A recent study examining the relative roles of social capital and income as determinants of happiness concluded, â€œCommunities and nations with better social capital, in other words, quality social networks and social norms as well as high levels of trust, respond to crises and economic transitions more happily and effectively.â€  We are hardwired for social connection. It is what enabled human beings to survive as a speciesâ€”in other words, our interdependence is critical to our well-being and ability to thrive. â€œNo democracy, and indeed no society,â€ says Putnam, â€œcan be healthy without at least a modicum of this resource.  What can we do?  Putnam argues that America could be civically restored by encouraging adults to socialize, join more groups, or volunteer more in the community. Another way he suggests is through teaching children the value of social connection.  The APA is working on an agenda to integrate social relationships into current public health priorities in a manner that is more consistent with the empirical research, which involves "directing resources, time, and energy to those issues that are deemed most critical and practical to addressâ€ . Some of the APA's recommendations include:  Greater priority on research and resources directed toward prevention efforts, education, public health policy and interventions. Greater emphasis on social skills training for children in schools. Doctors should be encouraged to include social connectedness in medical screening. People should be preparing for retirement socially as well as financially (many social ties are related to the workplace.) community planners should include shared social spaces that encourage gathering and interaction. All human beings desire to thrive, as do societies. Perhaps instead of moving further and farther away from one anotherâ€”geographically, socially, and politicallyâ€”a better option would be to lean closer together. Ultimately, if we are to learn to live with one another, we must come to the realization that we cannot live without each other.  References  Putnam, R.D. (2000). Bowling Alone: The Collapse and Revival of American Community. New York: Simon & Schuster.  Slater, P. E. (1970). The Pursuit of Loneliness: American Culture at the Breaking Point. Oxford, England: Beacon Press.  https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/nurturing-self-compassion/201901/isolation-nation

At 1:24:35 - Re Dr Gabor's comment on the Twelve Steps (AA, etc) not addressing trauma. The Fourth Step does Indeed address this, albeit in a subtle, compassionate and realistic manner. "... the exact nature of our wrongs..." The word "exact" is extremely loaded for anyone who has gone deeper into this step. It was worded this way, I believe, in awareness of the vast range of participants, in their variations of consciousness, self-awareness, personal history. Yet invited one to take it all the way if they could and/or wanted to.  The exact nature would include the origins of our" defects of character". In the 1940s when the 12 Steps were written (received), psychology was still  young. The very idea that character and personality formation were in large part due to our early environment was not currency as it is now. The risk of disturbing the myths of perfect parents and childhood happiness was great, and could have derailed a prospective healing and sobriety. The Twelve Steps left no stoned unturned, is the ultimate home-grown modern wisdom to this day. Somewhere in there will also be found, I trust, an 'opening' to recovery via plant-based drugs such as mushrooms, lsd, ayahuasca. It only takes a slower, deeper look, which I now intend to do. Please excuse all the words, and thank you for your attention.

Thereâ€™s a lot of good information here, and good insights, but with all due respect Dr. Gabor Mate is showing the age of his medical degree. In the past fifteen years neuroscience has advanced significantly. Substance abuse disorder is a brain disease caused by a combination of identified genetics and brain dysfunction caused by repeated dramatic dopamine surges resulting in feedback loops in two  important brain areas that result in a shutdown of the prefrontal cortex creating a condition called â€œhypofrontalityâ€ that impairs judgement, decision making and behavioral control. Heâ€™s right about so much but wrong on the science there. Thatâ€™s crucial. If you want to hear a thorough explanation of how addictive and compulsive behaviors are a medical illness as well as an emotional  illness watch â€œPleasure Unwovenâ€ by Dr. Kevin McCauley. The things Dr. Mate describes donâ€™t explain why childhood trauma makes some people addicts and others not, the answer is because of genes and gene expression. Much like Type II Diabetes. This is important because addicts feel shame and feel that they are bad people. Not everyone with the genetics for Type II diabetes become diabetic either, and yet you canâ€™t become diabetic unless you have that predisposition. That is why so many trauma victims do not ever become addicts.

Actually Dr. Mate is quite up to speed on the research and the neurobiology of trauma in terms of the developing child's brain changes, epigenetics and trauma research (The ACE Study, etc.).  The physiological changes produced by childhood trauma both wire the brain in patterns different than non-trauma experiences, AND can produce epigenetic changes that can pass to offspring.  To take this complex mix we are just beginning to better understand and do the typical Western reductionistic medical model routine of labeling something a "disease" strikes me as rather bizarre.  The ACE Study shows quite clearly the very powerful dose/response connection between multiple childhood trauma exposures and increased incidence of adult addiction later in life.  The medical model of addiction you are referring to is actually the "old model" of addiction that is being challenged powerfully by a constellation of cutting edge research from the ACE Study, to the ongoing neurobiological research into the impacts of trauma on the developing brain, and including breaking research in epigenetics.    Having worked as a therapist in addiction I am deeply grateful to the fact that we are better understanding the connection between childhood trauma and adult addiction.  The traditional medical model of "addiction" basically ignores childhood trauma as if the fact that all the neurobiological impacts on the brain mean nothing, and simply "stopping drinking" or "stopping using meth" will change everything.  I can assure you it does not.  One addiction is simply replaced by another unless trauma is addressed and people learn new ways to self-soothe, to manage stress, to deescalate triggering events, related to the impacts of that past trauma.  Mate's discussion of this around the 51 minute mark are right on the money with the current research.

I have a similar story with discovering or uncovering the real family history.  My family's official version is that my maternal grandparents met in Dachau (in Dachau!) when they were sent to Germany from different countries "for labour". They both survived (and died) holocaust without having that word in their vocabulary. My grandmother survived Stalin's hlodomor (before the word was coined) and  Hiyler's holocaust without knowing it.  In my thirties, I picked up some pieces of the puzzle and put it together. The biggest one being watching the german movie "Nowhere in Africa" when the main protagonist tells his wife that the short telegram she got from her sister telling her we (sister and mother) are being sent for labour to Poland for work means DEATH and how her sister wanted her to know... A fight breaks out between the two of them because she is a spoiled hausfrau and has hard time grasping the reality and he is losing patience with her.  Yelling at her "Your sister wanted you to know. " and envying her because he doesn't know what happened to his father.  They escaped Germany just in the nick of time and managed to land "Nowhere in Africa", today's Kenya, because they didn't have any money to emigrate anywhere else. That is when something clicked in me. Being sent "for labour" to Dachau, a concentration camp is not normal part of grandparents history.  My grandparents didn't know...It's like surviving the school residential system or Magdalene asylums but probably worse without knowing the term and being able to own and tell your own story and experience of it.

I don't know what it is about Gabor, his voice and delivery, but there are things he says that brings me to tears.  I think it's his tenderness around the pains we experience in childhood, and his compassion for loneliness and isolation in adulthood.

I struggle with the frustration that all these wonderful & promising modalities seem to be geared towards people with unlimited disposable income. Its easy to start wondering even where to begin chipping away at all that is involved here.  When my son overdosed 2 years ago I decided to work backwards starting with addiction treatment reform.  It blows me away that this antiquated system is being sold to the public as a solution for addiction when at best its a temporary respite from active substance abuse, a chance for the body and brain and worried loved ones to relax, but if they aren't getting any 'treatment" for the reason they began using in the first place I don't know why anyone would expect outcomes to be any different than the almost complete failure that these programs are.  At worst, they are exploitative scams where it is possible to pay outrageous fees only to leave in worse shape than you arrived.  In 4 years my son had been through 7 programs ranging in length from 30 days to 9 months and in most cases, especially those where he stayed multiple months trauma treatment was listed allegedly included and it was discussed, and also the need for it was confirmed by thieir own psychiatrist, yet shortly before my son died I realized that he had never received any treatment for trauma besides drugs to manage the symptoms! So, in other words exactly what he was doing on his own and the very reason he came to treatment to stop.  He was everything Dr. Mate described very sensitive, a wonderful songwriter and musician who wanted to live and he succeeded in every program in full compliance but he still died .  It is especially tragic when people are willing to do anything to help themselves, and there are therapies available, and even with the luxury of time they didn't manage to bring in EMDR, teach him EFT or anything for trauma, but in addition to go to countless 12 step meeting you know what he did get to do?  He got to jump out of an airplane, pet  horses and fly on a trapeze, but he didn't get any help with the core reason he used drugs to begin with.  How is this even allowed to go on?   This was an excellent interview!  Thanks to you both.

Quality interview. As far as using psychedelics under the watchful eye of an adept, as Gabor suggests, the issue is finding such a trustful adept in this world, and preferably someone that you don't need to jump on a plane to visit. You could chance it and take it with a friend who you think may be up to the task, but if they haven't dealt with their own internal pain it could easily go pear shaped.   I've been using psilocybin and Ayahuasca methodically for a couple of years, alone, and seen good results. Dose needs to be carefully measured every time. It is definitely risky, but taking these compounds in large group/ceremonial settings with unfamiliar people at an unfamiliar dose is also risky, if not more risky. Especially if it includes hundreds of years of cultural baggage via the popular South American shamanic setting. I don't deny i've bitten off more than I can chew a number of times- having sedatives on hand may save you from going insane. It's obviously best to try and avoid that scenario until you have done a shit tonne of shadow work and are ready to take the leap into nothingness with little resistance and then you realise it felt like going insane only from the perspective of the conceptual mind. If you are using for deeply spiritual purposes, at some stage you are just naturally going to bite off more than you can chew, in that there ain't gonna be a person there with which to chew anything.

What a really nourishing conversation this is - I've been a trauma therapist working with children and families for over 30 years - it's very reassuring to see how progress is being made in understanding the impact of trauma on human consciousness... which clarifies how our early experiences with trauma functionally shape what and how we perceive life.  And I'm not talking about just traumatic events - I'm including living on a traumatogenic planet which has been reeling with planeatry and species (as in the human species) catastrophobia that's been buried in our collective unconscious, and carried in our DNA, for a very, very long time.  I love Barbara Hand Clow's understanding about this too. Having been engaged in 'talk therapy' (within many creative and alternative modalities), personally I've found working with sound and frequencies to be faster, and more efficient - we can train our brains away from over-developed stress circuitry, and into states of consciousness connected to empathy and deep creativity, profound relaxation and compassion... and step into our own personal potential. That's how we create change on our planet.   Thanks for such a deep and wonderful conversation about what underlies human suffering.

Hi Karen. Yes, Robbins has a massive reputation here and usually has positive things to say. The way he presents his message is a bit over the top at times. This just goes to show how deep run the roots of internalized sexism. I suspect Robbins would not see himself as sexist, and for the most part he is likely one of the more open to change guys out there. The internalization process that oils the wheels of patriarchy and capitalism makes it hard to change. I discovered that I, too, have some internalized sexist beliefs about women. I learned this when I earned my college degree recently (English lit, sociology and gender studies). As a woman in my 60's, I grew up with a lot of indoctrination that I work daily to be aware of and to hold myself accountable for changing. That's the key...being willing to change and seeking new information when we discover that the initial information was incomplete and/or inaccurate. All of this leads to the suffering that Gabor Mate discusses so eloquently :)

I, too, was surprised how Tony Robbins' name crept up in this conversation. I am not up to date on his latest controversy. In any case,  he and his "you can will ourself out of anything" with positive, happy thoughts should stay where it belongs- in the past.

This is the same science that Self Regulation Therapy (SRT) has been based on for the last 20 years and why it's so successful in treating developmental gaps, early childhood trauma, and trauma of all kinds by regulating the nervous system - not just treating the symptoms. Definitely not by talk therapy. it's great to hear more professionals come along side to give more exposure to the neuroscience and ability to create new neural pathways in the brain and therefore increase resilience and heal the person. Different approaches than Mates' but same science and high efficacy especially for PTSD, anxiety, depression, etc. Working with trauma in a neurobiological way to discharge excess energy in the nervous system by completing thwarted fight/flight/freeze cycles creates a regulated nervous system with fewer symptoms and more room for resilience and joy. Brilliant two humans hash out addictions:  Human nature is one that uses the protective coping mechanism of dissociation and avoidance when we face trauma or pain.  "Trauma" is a loss of self. A disconnect from our present states because the situation is so overwhelming and shocking that we choose survival instead of fear and pain. What then is recovery?  To "re-cover" something is to re-find it. Recovery is therefore a reconnection with the self. Gabor talks about how the very meaning of "yoga" ("yo"-"ga: "mind"-"body") is that of connection with oneness; source, self, mind, body, whatever.  "Depression": to "de-press" something is to push it down. Depression is therefore an avoidance of feelings.  Instead of asking "why the addiction"? We look at "why the pain"?  Also: genetics plays less of a role in addictions than does upbringing. Back to my bread and butter which is the "stress" factor in health; a stressed out mother will have high levels of cortisol in her placenta, transferring this to the baby. This child will have significantly more issues from birth.  Whoa. Phenomenal, albeit long, watch.  If not for the sheer brilliance, then for the Tim Ferriss because #TimFerriss...or #GaborMate because #TheMan

To live fully in the present, all of the past has to die. Not forgotten, but forgiven, integrated, healed and released. To feel everything so fully that there is nothing left to carry forward, except you, present, here and now. Finally â€¦ fully human. To feel it all and be free of any left over contaminated experience, or relating and to know who (and what) you truly are; this is freedom. We each find our way through this inner landscape. Â @amandapoyner8141Â  wow Great summation I usually feel quite sad listening to Gabor Mate.. I am struck by the depth of his insights and their truth while simultaneously recognizing my almost complete failure to apply any of these insights or methods of personal inquiry to my own life/self. I am into my 60s wanting to do some kind of psychological salvage operation... been poking away at it for a decade, but never gained any traction. Introspection always leads to emotional churn with no insights nor resolution whatever. I feel doubly defective since I have no awareness of how I was traumatized - either by the presence of "bad" stuff or the absence of "good" stuff. I feel stuck in the zone between being so clueless that my narcissism is fully intact and causes no discernible grief, and so cluefull that my narcissism yields to introspection and shifts if not resolves. He talks about not really being able to live until one has confronted death - and that psychedelic experiences  can help get there. I engaged in medicine journeys specifically to find out what is broken and how to fix it, but haven't encountered death or ego-dissolution, or love or oneness with everything - any of the things people describe... just my self-centered self...

Â @kurtklingbeil6900Â  - The journey always brings us into direct conflict with our own shadow and sometimes the only thing one can do, is to feel â€¦ including surrendering to not knowing, to just feeling the 'churn' â€¦ the knowing comes, gradually; often when we stop trying. Just that act of internal surrender seems to unlock the resistance. And, I am thinking that if you were truly so narcissistic, you would not feel the 'churn' and that lack of feeling most likely points to dissociation, so that memories and feelings and connections to 'why', 'what', 'when' are hard to make. For me, a lot of it was past life, but I didn't get to that material until I had dealt with the patterns in this one. Maybe, it's hard to be here at all, so we feel lost between worlds and reluctant to be in the body; we can be ghosts in life. Keep going, at some point you will break though the membrane into clearer awareness. Good wishes for that.

I 100% see the culty ickiness to the whole JP memer crowd phenomena, but i think thats more a product of the world we live in... many people have literally nothing else to cling to in their lives... no direction no structure of ideas no encouragement no reassurance and absolutely no aim.. and mostly no fathers either... people cling to "him" as a person for these reasons and its a bad thing because it personalizes the information being communicated (just like with the personalization of "immoral" ideas on to a single individual like trump/hitler) it stops the message from being internalized and thus developed or refuted properly... which goes against JBs whole shtick of TAKE RESPONSIBILITY. It is infantilization when you see people's behavior as an involuntary consequent of their viewpoints or lack thereof. It's like putting a leash on a dog and saying "Your behavior is bad, you need to be trained". This is a fitting analogy of what's happening when you demand that people pursue meaning and then go into lengthy details of what meaning is while claiming that absence of meaning will cause them to become nihilistic and murderous and a danger to others. The constitution doesn't work like this, a man can pursue his own happiness providing he abides by laws that safeguard the liberty of others, the law holds you accountable except in cases of drug abuse where the law has to infantilize people and say, "If you do this then you will pathologize your environment." Peterson draws this line to everyone who does not pursue an articulated idea of 'meaningfulness' that conforms to a standard pattern within a societal structure because according to him these people WILL become pathological and we can't allow that.

I wouldn't worry about politicians, I would worry about the law and constitution, politicians as bad as they may be are still constrained by the law. If a person comes into politics saying he has 'the truth' that involves individuals to demonstrate their support to this indisputable truth or alternately suffer the label of 'pathological' then things get really disturbing. I don't see that people get to determine their own idea of 'meaningful' any more then they're allowed to determine  their own identity, i presume the future authoring program sets a criteria for 'meaningful pursuits', have a family, make money, be a productive community member and an inspiration to others, walk like a lobster and all the other stuff. I wonder what negative personality traits would show up in the result if you stated you wanted to do some traveling and find yourself. That's another thing with the personality tests, this is not science, he has drawn so many inferential conclusions about these tests that are speculative but it's his drive for ORDER that makes him want to categorize everything and everyone, obviously with consequences for people in those categories, it's so creepy and unlike anything that we have seen in politics.

there are many ways ones perception can be blinded/distorted/diverted/translated which would be varying degrees of "involuntary" behaviour, and when we strive to reduce ignorance to realistic ideas in ourselves we are minimizing the involuntary behavioural consequences of either holding incomplete viewpoints or lacking thereof. So the dependency on viewpoints being aligned with the reality you inhabit is a constant and has nothing to do with being infantile, its an ongoing process, if it wasn't an ongoing process we'd be ideologues. Look at it this way (i raise dogs lol and i like the analogies), you don't actually "train" a dog to walk on a leash  on good behaviour.. instead you simply walk.. and correct any misbehaviour before it has a chance to flourish into a full action / change of mindstate, its all done as you go along and it is quite literally a "balancing" act, especially so with the initial moments (just the same way we must balance our selves)  Secondly, youre not thinking he wants to legislate and enforce the idea of finding life meaning are you lol? dude he just teaches, if we want to judge his character on the respect for the integrity of the established laws that work, we have our example and its the reason he even exists to us to begin with, by no evident intention of himself either. The proposition given for happiness is as a consequence of living a meaningful life, we know happiness is not achieved by simply looking for it therefore the idea of "im gona find my own happiness somewhere dont tell me what happiness is" is only part of the picture, the safest way to define would be "happiness is achieved through balance within the mind and the body", which doesnt take away ANY ability to find ones self. Lastly if... "a sense of meaning" (the words "a sense" indicating subjectivity) is what produces happiness or contentment, (as a consequence of a balanced phsyche) then its safe to assume a continued lack of contentment will 100% lead to resentment given the right amount of time...  and continued, sustained resentment WILL lead to pathology(or another word you like) which will indeed sorely affect your surroundings, even if only by way of you not existing in the capacity you should be by your own admission (which is exactly the epidemic you see today, which is exactly the reason why extremists of all beliefs are the ones we let fight for our issues to see who wins now, instead of being a strong majority of citizens)
